description:
Hamachi truffle and Sizzling Mango Sea Bass. WOW.  I'll be honest with you, I haven't steered away from this course because it's so good I have to have it every single time I come here. Their menu is a bit limited anyway so this isn't my go-to sushi spot, but when I'm wanting something extra special or I want to impress a friend I'll come here and get that. 

Side note - this restaurant is tiny so don't try coming here with a large group.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I didn't ever think I'd call myself a rice snob, but now I realize that those Japanese food experts are right - it's really the rice that makes the sushi, not the fish.

Don't get me wrong, I like a fatty piece of otoro as much as anyone else, but good quality rice that's been cooked and seasoned perfectly separate good sushi and great sushi.  Both me and my dinner date felt like the rice had been overcooked, to the point where it wasn't fluffy but kind of mushy.  This made for really dense nigiri that felt a little clunky and off texturally.  The rice was also served a lot warmer than I'm used to, almost like it came right from the rice cooker.

The sea bass carpaccio was really nice and refreshing, but the sizzling sea bass roll was super overwhelming and drowning in sauce.  I liked the non-rice dished the most.  At the price we paid, I was just expecting a little more quality.  Would also like to see more variety in the nigiri section.

Tips and Tricks 
-Room at the bar when we went at 7:30 on a Thursday
-Stick with the raw stuff, fire cooked rolls are just for show
-Cute date spot, you can grab ice cream up the street or walk to Ghirardelli square
author: Jessica L.

description:
Going downhill...

I live in the neighborhood and had good memories of this place and came by last night. Food was not as described - poke bowl was more like a cucumber pasta with no seaweed and little tuna - and service was just bad. I get it to a certain extent since it's a high volume place but from sitting us down, no check ins, drop off of food like we are in an assembly line, sake with the top on that was hard for us to open, having to chase them down to refill our water, to stacking of chairs as there were patrons still eating... I mean the prices don't justify this lack of service. I won't be back.
author: M C.

description:
Price $$ 
Taste - *****

Best sushi restaurant in SF. I came here little late dinner around 8pm but I should wait for 1 hour( but worth it)

Inside was small. Tables are small and too close to other tables. 

Sashimi omakase - it was really really great. There were 6 kinds and 18 pieces of sashimi. They were all fresh and delicious. Even the simple sauce went well with Sashimi.

Toro sashimi - PLEASE EAT IT. It was best toro I have ever eaten. Soft fatty tuna was perfect. 

Spicy hamachi - it was simple roll but still good.

Flaming seabass - it was fancy firing roll. It was also okay. Sauce was tasty and hot rice with baked sea bass was good. Better than spicy hamachi.
author: Da Won L.

description: In a nutshell, place not to miss while visiting SF Russian Hill (comes from a local). Menu offers plenty of choices with focus on modern sushi fusion rather than traditional, that said I totally love the approach, variety and creativity. The must have list - Hamachi truffle, Himalayan trout, Yaman roll. Yes, most likely you'll have to wait for a table, plan on coming early or after first wave of customers leave and if not just stroll a bit in our beautiful neighborhood 'sip a glass of bubbly in one of wine bars while waiting for the sushi magic.
author: Zeev S.

description:
It was just the two of us so although the wait time was quoted for 20 minutes, we got in much sooner. Inside the restaurant, the tables were fairly close to one another, mostly designed for parties of two with a larger table in the back corner that can fit about 6-7 people. 

I saw a few people get the flaming sea bass but we decided to pass on that. We opted for the Himalayan trout which I can still imagine the flavors on my tongue. I even started to "dip" the other fish onto the block of Himalayan salt. You have to get this dish if you come here. 

I also want to highlight their housemade ginger that comes in a little jar. It is incredible! I was debating whether or not I should just drop that ginger jar into my purse. (I didn't.) 

We also got an assortment of sashimi to try- all very fresh. Among all, my favorites were the salmon and fatty trout.
author: Julie N.

description:
Elephant Sushi is a trendy/fushion-y Japanese spot. It's pretty small and intimate, so arrive when they open to get a better chance of scoring a table. 

The Himalayan Trout on salt rock is SO good! Melt in your mouth, buttery deliciousness - a must try. 

Seems like everyone loves the rolls here. The Ya Man roll with king salmon is really good. I usually dislike rolls, but I don't think I dislike the concept of rolls, I dislike the crappy fish you usually find in it. Well, the king salmon is delicious so I definitely wouldn't mind ordering this one again! 

We also got the Boom Box roll because the banana sounded interesting, but it was kinda weird.. 

We ordered hotate nigiri and the hotate was teeny tiny?!Other places usually give you a whole scallop, but they gave us half..? or maybe a third? 
 
I would definitely come back, but only if I didn't have to wait.
author: Laverne N.

description: Good date spot (mostly 2-person tables and has good vibes) but overrated as a go-to sushi joint. That one flaming roll is a crowd pleaser but I actually like two non-rolls more - the Yummy Pocket (spicy scallops stuffed in sweet tofu skin wrappers) and Beastie Boys (uni with quail egg) more. The Boom Box is unique (sushi with banana slices) but I would save it for the end of the meal given its sweetness, even if they bring it out first.
author: Jason X.

description:
I can agree with a lot of the comments here about the service. The food was okay. I'm not much of a fish person but my boyfriend enjoys it so we decided to go. We walked in while tables were available and got told that it would be 20 minutes for a table - understandable, so we put our name down on the list and went to a bar nearby. We got called 7 minutes in saying that our table was ready so we chugged our drinks and left the place. When we got back to Elephant Sushi we needed to wait an additional 15 minutes because the table WAS NOT ready. I was super annoyed at this point and hangry. 

The sushi was ok, lots of options for people who enjoy it. My boyfriend enjoyed it and thought it was decently priced. I'm giving it 2 stars because of the poor service/hostess.
author: Inci A.

description:
The owner of this establishment is a bully and is scary. We had a bill of over $200 for two people for a girl's night and were still eating. He gave us the check when we still had more food coming and said it was time for the next guests in line to sit down. We were there for 1.5 hours and I guess that isn't allowed? 

It was a very strange, mean experience and we left confused. If you look at other low rated reviews you will see his outrage and lashing out at customers. He was yelling at us to leave in front of the entire restaurant? I thought I was dreaming it?! His staff looked like they were afraid of him and I am sorry they have to work there! Find somewhere else to work. We all deserve a nice boss!

I live in the neighborhood and am sad to have this place here now.
author: Ann K.

description:
I think this may be the best sushi I've had in San Francisco! I'm already planning my next visit because of how amazing it was!

We ordered the Himalayan Trout on salt rock and it was incredible. So fresh and flavorful and something I've never seen anywhere else. The other standout was the "Flaming Halibut" which they bring to your table wrapped in foil and then put on a tray and light it on fire! It cooks table side for a while before the waitress comes back to unwrap it and you see that it's a baked roll. While the performance could be seen as overrated, it wasn't because the roll inside was incredible. So different from any other cooked roll I've had and packed with flavor!

We ordered a few other standard rolls and everything was so fresh and delicious, I couldn't get enough!

The thing to know before you come here is that the restaurant is super small and they don't take reservations. Your whole party must be there before they will give you a table. I got there at 6:15 on a Wednesday and didn't have a problem, but by 6:30 there were people waiting so be prepared! It's worth the wait though :)
author: Sophie S.

description: Tiny. Intimate. Definitely crowded. So, so good. The yummy pocket is worth your attention, and if you like that level of spice, continue on to the spicy hamachi roll.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Very disappointed on an important night. I brought a group of friends, ordered plenty of drinks and food and were rushed out. 
Tips: Order one roll at a time to prolong your stay.
author: Tanya B.

description:
This place literally lights my world on fire! And if you order the Flaming Seabass, it will literally be on fire.

Elephant Sushi is a small (VERY small) sushi restaurant that fits the capacity of 49 people (says the plaque on the wall), although they try to squeeze as many tables as possible in the small establishment so this is not for the claustrophobic. 

The first time I tried to come here, the waitress severely overestimated the wait time so I ended up at their competition nearby. This time around the wait was around 20-25 minutes on a rainy Thursday night so I decided to stick it through since it looked popular. 

From the outside you can already tell this is a cramped place. It was cold outside and the inside was humid from all the breathing humans. As soon as I walked in my glasses fogged. 

We got seated at the bar and it was great seeing the jedi masters at work upfront and personal. It was a real experience. We were delightfully seated in front of the older jedi master and you can tell he had years of masterful experience compared to the spring chicken apprentices beside him.

We ordered the Flaming Seabass because every gringo table seemed to order that, so why not? This was for production purposes clearly. Also ordered the Ya Man Roll because how can you say no to something named Ya Man?

The Ya Man roll was a salmon topped roll with fried onions inside and a sprinkling of fresh green onions on top. It was tasty but my breath was just in deep remorse after as I couldn't get the onion flavor out!

The Flaming Seabass was delicious just as it was showy! Not completely sure what was inside but it was topped with seabass and the flames cooked it into a chewy perfection. The sauce was tasty but I think they put a little too much and the flames made the rice really soggy and chewy but somehow it just works!

Definitely coming back here again maybe on a non busy night (is that even possible?!?!?!?!!)

When I saw at the bar I noticed they had 3 security cameras on one side and 1 security camera on the other in the front. Is there really a need for that much security presence in such a tiny space?

Also outside if you walk to your left theres a projector towards the wall projecting the restaurant's name. Uber flashy!
author: Connie M.

description:
The flaming sea Bass , Dragon Rolland and, Sea Urchin are chopstick licking good!
The romantic ambiance and excellent staff make this the place to dine.
author: Rick O.

description:
I came here on a Sunday night with my brother. The atmosphere was nice, if a little small, and the service was good, but the food was overpriced and surprisingly hit or miss. If you order the right dishes, I think this place could be phenomenal, but overall I wasn't very happy with the experience given the cost. I would recommend sticking to nigiri or sashimi and skipping the rolls. 

THE GOOD: 
- Blue Fin Fatty Tuna: just order a bunch of this and you will leave happy. It was truly incredible. It melts in your mouth, and even at 25 dollars (for about 6 pieces) it's hard to feel like you've been cheated.
- Uni-Tama: Uni with quail egg. It was not the best uni I've ever had but it was quite good, although overpriced for the quality at 16 for 2 pieces. 

THE BAD:
- White Out Roll: This hamachi roll didn't really come together. It included seared butterfish, cucumber garlic and truffle oil. It was a bit loosely rolled for my taste and the truffle oil felt superfluous; it dominated the flavor of the roll and didn't combine well with the hamachi.
- Naked Scallop Roll: scallop, crab and masago, wrapped in soy paper... But, surprise, it was full of mayonnaise too, and that's pretty much all it tasted like. This roll was actually really bad. I love sushi and I couldn't eat it. 

Overall, Elephant might be worth a trip for the nigiri/sashimi but San Francisco has no shortage of sushi and you could find a better overall menu for your buck.
author: Benjamin S.

description:
The food here was not any different from any other sushi restaurant. However, their Sea-bass Sushi was worth the wait. The wait at this place is very long and they don't accept parties more than four. 
I personally thought  that the service here was not good. The hostess was very rude. 
The only reason I would come back here would be for their Sea-bass Sushi. Its really good.
author: Deki T.

description:
1 Star strictly because the food is great. You can't deny that. 

But this is SF, you're not special. 

This was a neighborhood favorite. I took an out of town girlfriend here on a Wednesday night for a belated birthday celebration. I was embarrassed for what unraveled. After spending $150+ for 2 people we were ASKED TO GET UP AND LEAVE. I'm sorry what?? Surely I heard that wrong...

Nope. My ears work and we've been told 3 different times to leave the sushi bar as "our time is up". I'm sorry, there's a time limit??? Maybe advertise that as service, experience, and ambience are huge components to eating out. Best part is we walk out to a only a party of 4 waiting....

I won't be back.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Excellent but hard to get a table if you don't get there around open. 
Fish is very fresh. Portions are good. Nice intimate dining experience. Reasonable prices to boot. 
Highly recommend the omakase (ours had butterfish, maguro tuna , salmon, yellow tail, sea bass?, and scallops. The scallops had a hint of a lemon sauce and the sea bass had a hint of yuzu sauce) and toro nigiri.  
We also got the flaming sea bass. It comes on fire, which is fun.
The dinner was well paced and we never felt rushed.  Very good.
author: D K.

description:
You know what's great about eating in San Francisco when everyone else is out of town? No line at Elephant Sushi yay! (And this is not one of those places tourists come to so double yay)

The space is pretty cozy and intimate with some interesting wood art in the shape of fish on the walls which are painted to look like concrete but isn't.

The rolls were overall alright. The one with the butter fish was a bit bland in my opinion but I really enjoyed the scallop snow crab combo. (As you can see, I didn't bother remembering the names of the rolls). 

EXCEPT THE BEASTIE BOYS. Holy shit. Sea urchin, ankimo (monk fish liver), and a fresh quail egg in one bite? HELL YEAH. Order this. You will not regret it? Unless you don't like delicious stuff. Then you'll hate it. In which case you don't deserve it anyway. 

Overall with drinks $50pp which is not suuuuuper cheap but not super expensive either. It'll satisfy your sushi craving either way.
author: Eunah T.

description:
When the fish is so fresh, it's blasphemy even contemplating dipping those luscious bites in soy sauce. Every dish we ordered was amazing. Top 3 of my night were the trout on the slab of Himalayan salt, the uni/monkfish liver/quail egg combo and the double albacore. So immensely gratifying! Not a sake lover by any means but the bottle ordered was incredibly smooth like a criminal. Haha

The best part was the surprise seating when we practically gave up when they said they initially couldn't accommodate 6. Kudos to our gastronomically gifted GF for not giving up.
author: Julie L.

description:
I still am the quest to find the best sushi places in San Francisco. I went here randomly on with a friend around 7 PM on a weeknight. We didn't have a wait because there weren't people out but I could see how the line could pile up.

The inside would accommodate less than 20 people. The ambiance is very intimate and I actually prefer it to the more bigger and commercial restaurants. If you like your elbow room I would recommend elsewhere as the space is very limited on the table. I would highly recommend the place for date night. 

Food wise. We ordered the Himalayan Trout (a must!), Ya Man roll and Beastie Boys together. I can't eat shellfish so I am always limited when I got to sushi places. Anyways, The fish was fresh, every dish we ordered was good. Price-wise I would say that you would pay around the same or a little bit less for the same amount. I would pay here for the novelty and atmosphere. 

I would return.
author: Amica J.

description:
This is my second time here at Elephant Sushi and I came back with my girlfriends for that Flaming Sea Bass and that very flavorful and interesting banana topped Boom Box sushi roll! The rolls are very delicious and the fish has been very fresh both times! I want to give this place 5 stars and was hoping they were a new go-to sushi spot, however the service and staff are TERRIBLE! I simply cannot justify going to a restaurant only for their food anymore. It's not wise nor common courtesy for a customer to come to a restaurant, enjoy their delicious meal, enjoy the beautiful company of friends, and after 5 minutes of paying - BE ASKED TO LEAVE by the waiter! We literally paid and 5 minutes passed while one of my friends was finishing up a story. Not 10, not 20, 5 minutes. Mind you, we waited 45 minutes for our table. 

Don't take away the dining experience of your customers. It's very rude and obnoxious and only reflects greed on your behalf as a restaurant and service. 

It doesn't matter how busy you are or accommodating you want to be. I was born and raised here and this is the first time I've ever been asked to leave a restaurant in SF and I only wish I was sitting much longer at that table after I paid. 

I can honestly say the food is delicious, so if that's your type of place (45 minutes to an hour wait, scarf down sushi within 30 minutes, pay & leave IMMEDIATELY, plus terrible service) - this is your place!
author: Zaynab H.

description: Weird service. Every. Time. Rushed out the door after eating, rude at the door. Food: Himalayan trout is magic, lovely buttery.
author: AMY M.

description:
Consistently good food. I've been here several times over the past few years and have always been impressed.  Prices are a bit more than 2 dollar Yelp signs, but you can taste the quality in the food so definitely warranted.

Not many sushi places have toro sashimi or sea bass anything but they do and it is a must try when ordering.

The flaming sea bass roll is a must if not just for the experience of having sushi bake on an open flame on your table for 10 or so minutes. It is also delicious and definitely unique in its cooked slightly charred flavor.  A bit too much sauce for my liking but that's a personal preference. 

Each roll we ordered was delicious and had a more than decent amount of fish.

The sea bass sashimi was bomb and flavorful and the cut of fish was gratuitous. 
The (Mongolian) waitress with the amazing cheekbones was kind, attentive (without being overbearing) and dealt with our requests for recommendations skillfully.  She definitely knows the menu well.

Please note, if you want a table, come as doors open or be ready to put your name down and go get a drink at a nearby bar.  This place is popular for a reason.
author: Natasha B.

description: The sushi here is OK. Nothing super fantastic. We ordered about four rolls here and the one that impressed us the most was the simple yellowtail roll.
author: James D.

description: This place used to be so good... but tonight's meal was subpar. Most of the rolls were lack-luster with the exception of the flaming sea bass roll.... which is quite a spectacle - but not a traditional sushi roll. The ambience is fun but the drinks/wine list is pretty light with fewer options. Rating it 3 stars is generous. Kazan in the mission is way better.
author: Gulshan L.

description: This place blew me away! Super fresh, good portions, unique options, friendly staff. I will definitely be back any time I'm in the area!
author: Lee A.

description:
Oh man this place is making you a favor that they  serve you ! 
Place is tiny overcrowded and tables are small, and they short on stuff and make you wait for a while for anything , need to ask couple time for everything if you are lucky enough! 
Fish is ok , but not really worth it ! not going back , there is much better places to go and enjoy food.
I wish they now what customer service is.
author: Askhat E.

description:
Good sushi, fresh fish, and interesting rolls. Well, fairly interesting anyway. A lot of the menu appears to be spiced with togarashi. Not a huge problem if you're into spicy rolls, but could be a little monotonous. 

Still, we had a great meal tonight and really enjoyed most everything we ate.
author: Sharat G.

description:
Elephant Sushi is our casual go to neighborhood sushi spot. Most of the tables are for two, so it's a great date spot or place to catch up with a friend 1x1. We used to come for the rolls, but recently discovered that their nigiri is on par as well. It is super fresh and the pieces are generous in size (and we are omakase fans). Highlights include the ocean trout & walu, and the chips n dip to start with.

A few things to note:
-We've rarely had to wait but the few times we have, it was much shorter than quoted. If you do grab a drink in the area (Union and Larder!), order something chuggable because your table may be ready sooner than you expect
-Elephant is closed on Monday's and Tuesday's, which you can relate to if you've ever craved Chik-fil-a on a Sunday
author: Autumn R.

description:
Been wanting to go here for a while and finally made it out on a friday night. Wait was estimated to be 2 hours long but about an hour in, we got the call :). There's a bunch of bars in the area so we just waited till then.

Food highlights: Favorites were the himalayan trout and Ya man roll (this was recommended by our server and we ended up getting seconds it was so good!). White out roll was good. I thought the Flaming sea bass was underwhelming. And the naked scallop I would not order again (very blah).

Ambiance and service was great.
author: Laura D.

description:
What a cute place to grab some dinner. Got there on saturday a little after opening and got seated right away.  They did have a line! Tried the flaming seabass roll that everyone raved about ($17 roll) thats on fire and one with salmon called the ya man roll. The seabass one sounded really special as it cooks over heat in front of you for 5 minutes. It has a nice spicy kick and a lot of heat but i actually couldn't separate any of the tastes or flavor in it to be honest. I enjoyed the ya man roll more for the fresh salmom and garlic.  

Both the rolls were good but pricey and not very very memorable. I appreciated the flavors and the fresh salmon but it wasnt the best sushi ive had, definitely not for that price. But service was great and the environment was cool too. I wouldn't mind trying out their other rolls as they all sounded good but it is a little expensive and not groundbreaking sushi. But don't get me wrong, its good.
author: Dana O.

description:
I'm having a tough time deciding how I feel about this restaurant. First of all great ambiance/date spot/small though so big parties or even children would be difficult. Service was friendly and on top of refills etc. 

We ordered: the flaming Seabass-a little different in flavors but certainly entertaining and keeps you warm!, the white out-I really liked this roll, the omakase sashimi-a good variety and amount of fish offered, and finally the beastie boys-the biggest highlight in my book and a perfect way to end the meal. 

Everything was good but I wouldn't say it was amazing enough for me to want to come back. I could see why many others may like it but parking was rough and for the price point it wasn't horrible. A-ok in my book. On to the next sushi spot.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Had a very enjoyable meal at elephant sushi this past weekend. As others have said, it's very small, so we had to put our names in and come back about an hour later for the table. You can leave and they'll call you when the table is almost ready.

We had the flaming sea bass, the naked scallop, a spicy tuna roll, uni nigiri, rainbow, and a few others that I can't recall. They were all pretty tasty, but I think the naked scallop was my favorite. The sea bass presentation was fun, and it was good, but I think because it was covered in unagi sauce. The uni wasn't the best quality, but still a decent portion for the price. Everything was good, and I left decently full for a reasonable price.  

The service is quick, the space is intimate, beers/sake aren't expensive, and the food is good.
author: David H.

description:
WORST. PLACE. EVER.
In case you don't want to read to the end, I'll start with the highlight. THE OWNER FLIPPED US OFF IN THE MIDDLE OF HIS RESTAURANT!!! Do yourself a favor and read all the other 1 star reviews and you'll see they don't care at all about their customers. Which is also apparent from their 61/100 health food score!! See link below...

I met a friend for a ladies night out. We had been there 2 yrs prior and were NOT IMPRESSED!! Their flame rolls are awful.... However, we decided to give them another try. So we met up and were just gabbing, sharing a bottle of sake, & casually ordering items to share. We had just placed another order when the hostess came up to tell us we'd been there too long. Not once had anyone told us there was a time limit. We explained that this was awkward and that we had just ordered another item. So we told her "Fine- we'll leave so please cancel our order & bring us the check"... After paying we then asked to speak with the manager. We are now awkwardly standing in the middle of their tiny restaurant and it is becoming clear that NO ONE has any intention of coming to speak to us. We then walked to the door and I bothered the hostess and said that we weren't leaving until we spoke to the manager. Huge mistake!! A very aggressive man came out and identified himself as the manger/owner. We expressed how rudely we were treated by his staff, and his response was to tell us "I don't care!! I'm busy!! Get the fuck out!!", and then FLIPPED US OFF IN THE MIDDLE OF HIS RESTAURANT for all the other guests to see.

Do yourself a favor and go around the corner to Okoze. They have the nicest staff and amazing cuts of fish!! That truly is my fave sushi spot!! Wish my friend & I hadn't decided to try something different... won't be making that mistake again.

https://101g-xnet.sfdph.org:8443/ords/f?p=132:2:::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:69512
author: Amy T.

description: Absolutely love this place. I am not typically into rolls but these guys know what they are doing. Make sure you get the Himalayan trout.
author: Dayris F.

description: A truly terrible experience.  The service was the worst I have encountered in San Francisco.  We sat down at 9pm, ordered all at once like our server asked us to, and by 9:21pm, we were handed a bill for $96.  Our server asked us to pay now, so she could close the register.  We had most of our food in front of us.  It wasn't enough that they had stacked up all the chairs on top of the tables around us to let us know they wanted us to leave- that just wouldn't have been a big enough hint on their part.  When I told them that they shouldn't have seated us if they wanted us out in 20mnts, it was like talking to a stone wall.  We paid $96, left in anger with most of our food still on the table, and had to listen to someone say "thank you" on our way out.  Incredible.  They just don't care at all.
author: peter d.

description:
I've been to Elephant twice, and live in the neighborhood. It's sushi is good, above average but not extraordinary and priced medium/high, so not great value.

Why I'm writing a review is because of the service both times. It's the bottom I've experienced in SF. Hard to flag down severs, no return except to bring the food (eg, water, check ins) and the feeling of being rushed. Many reviews share this vibe. 

The environment feels high energy because of how small it is. I won't go back because there's plenty of other above average sushi restaurants in the neighborhood that seem to value customers and make the experience a multiplier for the dining. 

If you go to Elephant expecting poor service, you should meet or exceed expectations.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I LOVE elephant sushi. 

I am spoiled because I can go home and get homemade, authentic Japanese food (thanks, mom). I also am skeptical of fusion..but especially Japanese as I get nervous about messing up the classics. But Elephant Sushi is my one exception to the rule. Whenever a friend is visiting from out of town I have to take them here..to treat them...and myself!

My favorites are the Himalayan trout (on a beautiful salt block so ya gotta eat it ASAP), the Ya Man Roll, and Boom Box. 

Wash it all down with a Sapporo and it will be a good day I promise.
author: Zoe T.

description: Flaming sea bass was incredible. Himalayan trout is also a must! Double Albacore was okay not my favorite but still very delicious. There will always be a wait but there are so many spots around the area to grab a drink to make your wait easier. Amazing sushi - thank you Elephant Sushi!
author: Blanca C.

description: Called ahead for a reservation, and we were told to come and walk in. Arrived 45 mins before close on Fri night. Unsmiling girl at the door refused to take our names for the list upon arrival. No apology. No eye contact. No nothing. Went around the corner and had a fantastic meal and outstanding service at Okoze Sushi. Boo Elephant boo!
author: Meems C.

description: This is probably one of my favorite sushi places in San Francisco. Everything is always fresh and tasting delicious, I'm yet to have a bad experience at this place. If you want fresh and delicious sushi this is your place, you will not be dissatisfied. I've noticed that if you want to eliminate the wait time, it's best to come right before they open. This way you pretty much guarantee yourself a table.
author: Roman L.

description:
I'm 75/25 on how I feel based on the dishes I had.

1. Himalayan Trout - AMAZING...so fresh and fatty. Like silk in my mouth. I'd go back for this alone
2. Sea bass flambé (I totally made the name up, but that's essential what it was) - I felt very meh about this one
3. Various nigiri - fresh, comparable to your standard good sushi spot
4. Hello Kitty Martini - lychee flavor without being overbearingly sweet. Worth it.

Vibe: small place with tables close together. A bit loud, so maybe not a great first date spot unless you want a lot of that empty nod/smile where you know he/she has no idea what you just said.  Long lines here at prime time, but you can put in a name
author: Mon T.

description:
One of my favorite sushi restaurants in the city!! The most important tip I have is to come RIGHT WHEN IT OPENS at 6!!! Or else, you may have to wait up to an hour for a table lol... 

All of the sushi and rolls are super fresh! My favorites are:
- White out roll (hamachi, avocado, and seared butterfish = match made in heaven!)
- Ya man roll (salmon here is sooo buttery and goes great with the onion chips!)
- Walu carpaccio/trufflle hamachi, both are delicious! Both are the same ingredients (truffle oil, fried garlic, ponzu, and scallions) but the fish is different. 
- Double albacore roll (sweet teriyaki and honey mustard sauces are yummy)
- Flaming seabass roll (it's on fiyaaaa when it gets to your table--also the only "baked" roll)

On my most recent visit, I got to try the hello kitty martini, which has sake, soju, yuzu (japanese lime juice), lychee, and a maraschino cherry! This drink does not sound strong at all, but my bf and I actually got a nice buzz from it! It also had a tasty lychee flavor. I would order this again! The sake bombs sound fun too (and only $2), but keep in mind the beer glass is only 1/3 full haha.

My last thing to add is the great customer service here! All the waitresses are really friendly. I dropped one of my chopsticks at one point (i'm so embarrassing haha), and right when I looked up, I guess the waitress nearby heard it drop and she told me she would get me another one right away!!! My bf and I were so amazed at her hearing because it's pretty loud in the restaurant haha. Another example of their good customer service was when one of our rolls (double albacore) was taking a long time, and a waitress brought us a complimentary half portion of the hamachi truffle to say they were sorry for the wait! Super sweet of them. :-)

I will definitely be back!
author: Tara A.

description: I came here on a Friday night and only waited about 15 minutes for a table. Super friendly staff and the sushi was even better than I expected. Got the chips and dip and expected a lump of tuna tar tar with chips but the tuna was spread across a few chips as a bed, still good. The red and yellow was probably my favorite roll, I was a little worried the mango might take over the taste, but it was really subtle and made it even better. The flaming (literally) seabass was interesting! They lit it on fire to cook at our table, people were stopping on the sidewalk as they were walking by to take pictures of it.
author: Jared M.

description:
Its not zushi puzzle or akiko but its the best thing in the Russian Hill area and its half the cost of the other two places. They don't have special fishes but it is always fresh. My favorites are **Beastie Boys. Two pieces. Comes with sea urchin, ankimo, quail egg & shiso, two piece nigiri. One bite, so good. **Salmon Tataki. Fresh, super yummy. Its cured on himalayan rock slat, jalapeno, fresh leeks, chili, garlic ponzu, house basil oil & heirloom tomato. Also really like their Hamachi Truffle. That truffle oil goes so well with the hamachi. Made with truffle oil, ponzu, garlic chips & scallion. Brings out the flavor of the yellow tail. YUM! 

You can make reservations, which is recommended or be there at 6pm when they open. I normally like sitting at the bar because I love watching the chef make my food.
author: Sandy B.

description: Not sure what the hype is. The rice was very soggy and too vinegary. Some of the rolls get a little too creative with their flavors and ingredients leaving a confusing taste. Not authentic sushi at all and would not go back.
author: Christine D.

description: Best Sushi I've tried in my life. Located in Russian Hills, SF off of Geary st. Small little place yet worth the wait as they always have a waiting list. Try their sizzling sushi which they prepare in front of you.
author: Zunaira C.

description:
Not what I was expecting.
Rolls are catered to certain palate, non-traditional for sure. Most dishes are heavily doused in some kind Americanized, or sweet sauce. Granted there's a flare of creativity, but at the cost the flavor of the freshness (of the fish). This includes the Flaming Sea Bass and the Giants Roll. 

The staff and service is alright.
Did I mention they don't have green tea, they serve (something similar to) the brown buckwheat tea instead.

Feels like a hype for the price/location; not one I'd revisit.
author: May W.

description:
Delicious! Super small, make a reservation ahead of time.

We had all sorts of rolls. My favorite was the dragon roll! Great quality and great flavor!
author: Reviewing R.

description:
I was so so excited to get a reservation here with my boyfriend and his cousins. We got to our reservation right on time and they proceeded to seat us at our table. Once we sat down, had our coats off and had gotten comfortable, the hostess realized our 4th person wasn't there yet. She and the sushi chef proceeded to cause a scene and yell at us to get out of our table and wait outside for our 4th person...who arrived one minute later. If they had asked us upon arrival if our whole party was there, I would have completely understood that they wouldn't seat us. However, I think they went about it in a very rude, loud, and embarrassing way so we did not end up eating there. I can't believe they would treat potential diners that way so I will not be back. 

Long story short, make sure you are on time (only hold reservations for 5 minutes) and have your whole party otherwise plan on getting yelled at.
author: Kacey A.

description: Great sushi spot. We waited about a half hour on a Saturday around 8pm. Between the two of us, we got the flaming sea bass, ya man roll, spicy tuna roll, and one order of the omekaze sashimi (around 16-18 pieces for about $40). Everything was great, especially the sea bass. For the sashimi, they really don't hold back on the portion size of each piece of fish, it was an amazing value for the amount and quality of fish we got. They also were flexible enough to switch out one of the types of fish for another.
author: Shabnam E.

description: Went here exclusively because the reviews were so good and we were not disappointed. We took the advice to show up exactly as they opened and we were glad we did. We sat down right away and not soon after they started turning people away until later that night, the place is truly tiny. Our server was sweet and helpful. We really went all in for the hits, salt cured trout (perfection), flaming sea bass (too much mayo, but a unique and delicious gimmick), the godzilla (interesting combination) and the whiteout roll (san francisco has made me a butterfish addict). We scarfed everything down, it was really delicious. We would have ordered more but the prices were rather high so we decided to move on to cocktails elsewhere and had a snack later that night which is a pretty standard sushi tactic the bf and I practice. But it was a great experience overall.
author: Rayannin S.

description:
Totally worth the wait! Elephant sushi has been on my list for a while, so I was delighted when my sister and I both agreed to go here. 

The Wait: We figured that there shouldn't be a big problem getting in at 6:30 on a Saturday for 2 people especially when it opens at 6, but there was already a 45 minute wait. @&$! I was already hungry on the way to hangry at this point but we decided to walk around the area and wait. I really like that they take your number and give you a call when a table is about to open up. The wait ended up not being that bad and we got a great seat at the bar, which is so fun.

Food: 3 words- Sashimi Garden Salad! Originally we ordered the carpaccio as our starter, but after seeing the couple next to us get the sashimi salad, promptly changed our order to that. If you like poke, you'll love this! It's like a poke bowl with fresh vegetables-think kale, heirloom tomatoes, and more- with a delicious dressing. It's also a pretty large portion. One of the most creative, refreshing, filling, and delicious sushi items I've ever had! 

We also got the red and yellow roll and the Giants roll. Both were delicious and fresh. The rolls here are pretty big and filling compared to other sushi places. 2 rolls + the sashimi salad was enough for the 2 of us to be full and just have enough room for gelato after. I think the red and yellow roll was over sauced though. Fish and ingredients this fresh don't need so much sauce to mask the flavors plus there's already so much going on that it didn't need so much sauce or even soy sauce or wasabi. 

Service: Our waiter was funny and very down to earth. He took our order promptly, wasn't overly attentive but it was busy and the sushi chef was in front of us, refilled our water, and gave us the check quickly once we asked.  I also didn't feel rushed despite that there was a long wait so that was good.  The sushi Chef was awesome. 

Hot tip: It's on United Mileage Dining so you can get airline miles while eating here! Points + sushi, two of my favorite things. Also sit at the bar for a more fun experience. 

Overall: No it's not authentic sushi, but who cares!? It's some of the most creative food and is yummy in my tummy. Delicious, fresh, really unique and creative, decent service, worth the wait!
author: Alison B.

description:
Dang. We came here on the recommendation of a friend who said it was "the best sushi I've ever had." Based on other reviews, we arrived before they opened to ensure a table. We were the first in line at 5:40pm and by the time they opened at 6pm, there was a line that would fill over half the restaurant.

We sat down and started ordering: omakase sashimi, spicy tuna roll, a tempura roll, a salmon roll, beastie boy, and based on restaurant recommendation: the Himalayan trout. Needless to say, we left happy. The sashimi is the golden child - fish that literally melts in your mouth. Our favorite item was a toss-up between the trout and the scallops off of the sashimi plate. As other reviewers have said, it's definitely more expensive than other sushi restaurants, but that's because it's in a league of its own. I would definitely pay the same to go again.
author: Katie M.

description: Somewhat disappointed experience. We had blue fin tuna sashimi, ocean trout nigiri, white dragon roll and inari. All the fish are losing texture and doesn't feel as fresh. All the nigiri have relatively bigger rice portion and fish was sliced on the wider and thicker side - feeling not as authentic. When white dragon comes up, the halu feels water boiled vs. sealed/aburi. After that we just canceled everything that's not prepared and walked out.
author: Kathie F.

description:
Heard so much about this place, it had been on my list for a while and finally got to try it.

Elephant Sushi is a small restaurant with about 12 tables and they don't take reservations, therefore better to come in small groups or be ok with long waiting times. 

For a party of 2 we didn't have any issues on a Sunday night and got seated really fast. They're usually busy but are fast serving.

We ordered some rolls, the albacore roll was good and the flaming seabass was absolutely delicious, definitely a must have if you come here. 

Cons: they don't have miso soup or seaweed salad.
Pros: inexpensive good enough sushi.
author: Marta V.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan!

This place is great, I really enjoyed the Himalayan trout on salt rock. 
OMG, the salt rock did WONDERS! You wouldn't need soy sauce w/ this :)  

I originally came here to try the hamachi w/ truffle, which was great but the truffle taste was super faint. 

The rolls here are really just a hit or miss. 
I really enjoyed the white out roll, which literally melts in your mouth. However, I wasn't a fan of Red & Yellow (too sweet).

Also ordered the sashimi Omakase, which was really good and fresh! Everything was slightly pre-seasoned, which made it much more amazing.
author: Leilani Y.

description: The BEST sushi!!! So fresh and such good quality for a great price. Get there early though as it gets crazy busy! The Himalayan kampachi is to die for!
author: Sophie S.

description: AMAZING! We were so lucky to get in! They don't take reservations, but we went on a Thursday night and luckily they had space at the bar! We got the Himalayan trout, Spicy Salmon Roll, and Red Dragon roll. They were all amazing! The spicy salmon roll was good, but I would be a bit more adventurous when I come again. The Himalayan trout and Red Dragon Roll I will get every time!! So so good! And honestly would have waited if I had to!
author: Samantha M.

description:
Came on a Wednesday night about 30 minutes after they opened and luckily didn't have to wait for a table! They only have table of 4 & 2 so don't come with a large group!

Sat down and ordered a bunch of rolls - but my favorite would definitely be the Flaming Seabass - not because it's on fire and cooking in front of you.. but because it's full of flavor & filling!

I don't really have any complaints - but definitely on the more pricier side! Their service is quick - the waitress there are very attentive - always coming back to see if you want anything else to order (which you probably do) and rolls come out quick! 

I've heard horror stories about their lines, so hopefully next time I come I get lucky again!
author: Carrie L.

description: Always a staple in my books. This place never disappoints!! Get the Himalayan salt trout, it'll melt in your mouth.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Flaming Sea bass- a MUST!

Boom box- Another YUMMY one. 

The wait- LONG

Worth it- YES! Absolutely!

Parking- Ridiculous - Uber if you can!

Area- romantic, hip, trendy (I love it)

I definitely recommend eating here.
author: Muneera M.

description:
BEST sushi I've had in SF!!

Ambiance: A very cute restaurant, but VERY small. They only take reservations at 6pm right when they open, and if will only seat you if your whole party is there (you have a 10 minute grace period). Otherwise, the wait can be up to 1 1/2 hours.

Food: Omg so good. We go the walu carpaccio and spicy tuna & chips for appetizers. The walu carpaccio (butterfish with scallions, soy ginger sauce and some other stuff) was AMAZING. Butterfish is my new favorite thing. 5/5 for sure. The spicy tuna and chips was also really good, but I personally didn't love it as much. 4/5

For Rolls we got The Flaming Seabass, White Out, and Red and Yellow. They honestly were all amazing. I give them all 4.5/5. My favorite thing was definitely the walu carpaccio
author: Jenna G.

description: Ugh, two days later and I'm still thinking about the food here. I love sushi and I'm so glad I got to try this place out. I had a bunch of other sushi place bookmarked but when my friend had to work. I decided to ask her bf to come here with me, otherwise I would have just dine here alone. Wait was 20-35 min which is NOT bad at all considering the wait for places in Seattle is always doubles that haha.  Anywho, we decided to run down the hill for dessert before dinner because it makes sense haha. Came back and we were seated. I don't remember what my friend order but he really liked it. I ordered the bestie boy and the Godzilla then his gf said she was getting off work early so I ordered her the white out and the Dragon roll? Everything was SO good! I love that the godzilla roll I had order wasn't like the rolls I got back home. I'm already planning on coming back here when I come back in May!
author: Linh N.

description:
As you might suspect from the non-seafood, non-Japanese related name, Elephant Sushi is a modern, fusion-interpretation on sushi. But don't let that stop you from coming! It's a great bang for your buck relative to most SF eateries.

A waiter will come and get your name/number for the waitlist at the door. Make sure you answer the phone call, or they'll skip you! Our wait (for two) turned out to be just 15-20 minutes, so it really wasn't that bad. And we had time to read all the hilarious Feedback notes from various customers taped to the glass walls. And notice the logo being projected onto the wall of the next building outside. 

The inside is tiny and dimly lit, with a bar in the back and larger table partially sectioned off on one side. Mostly couples dining here, though it's not a particularly romantic setting and you have to talk pretty loudly to be heard. All the waiters were super friendly and efficient. There's some serious hustle going on to keep the line of people moving, so I wouldn't plan on staying here past an hour and a half or you'll start getting some heavy-handed hints. One couple was politely kicked out after breaking the longest stay record of 2.5 hrs. 

The menu is small but manages to be overwhelming. You've got appetizers, salads, sushi, nigiri, sashimi, seafood entrees, drinks, and... one dessert. A jar of ginger and some wasabi was delivered to our table after we ordered. I wanted to order some more Yummy Pockets and stuff them in MY pockets for later because they were so delicious. But they would have fallen out everywhere and exposed me for the pig (elephant?) I am. The Uni was okay, and the Spicy Hamachi failed to impress, but the Flaming Sea Bass is a must. I love baked rolls (not a raw meat kind of girl), and this one was flamed to perfection in front of our eyes. 

$2 Sake Bombs. Do it.
author: Helen S.

description: Perhaps not the best in town, but the one that I want to eat the most, and that's something special. Good price, the atmosphere is good but too loud, very bad acoustic and small place.
author: Nicolás A.

description:
Highly recommend this restaurant if you're craving sushi! Be prepared to wait if you don't have reservations since the place is small and really popular. We came on a Sunday night and there was a 30 minute wait but at least the neighborhood is nice to walk around.

The restaurant is pretty dark inside and I liked the atmosphere. The service was nice and quick even though they were extremely busy. We ordered the chips n dip ($10) which was spicy tuna, garlic pita chips, scallions & honey mustard sauce. It was a great combo of flavors and reminded me of ahi poke. Don't expect a large tray of chips though it comes with 4 small servings.

For the sushi we tried the Ya Man Roll ($12) which was salmon and unique flavors of fried red onion chips, pesto and ponzu. The waiter said this was one of their most popular rolls and it ended up being my favorite. The other highlight of the meal was the flaming seabass roll ($16). Everyone seemed to be getting this! They wrap the roll in aluminum foil in a dish with vodka and light it on fire for about 10 minutes to cook. It was super saucy and baked when it was done. Highly recommend you try it!

Also got the double albacore roll (very good but nothing too memorable) and unagi roll $10 (large servings of tender eel but not as flavorful as the other rolls). I really can't wait to go back to try the other rolls! The prices are also very reasonable for the interesting flavors you get here.
author: Linda X.

description:
Great sushi loved it.will.be back when im  in sf 
Great ambiance 
Great service and great suki 
will be back
author: Danni S.

description: I had this place bookmarked and finally had the chance to visit recently. Top things to get are the Himalayan trout, flaming sea bass and the Hamachi truffle. All of it was soo good, I wanted more, but had to resist. Overall good dining experience with great service.
author: Matthew L.

description: Excellent sushi. You must try the flaming seabass! The service was great. It is a smaller place that makes it more intimate for a perfect date.
author: Rique G.

description: Disappointing. Didn't get to eat here - we arrived as they opened on a Sunday with a group of 3. They would not seat us and advised they only have one table for 3. They would not combine tables, give us a table that seats 4 nor pull up a chair. No others were waiting to be seated- plenty of open tables. After waiting to see if they would be flexible they would not so we left.
author: Kelly O.

description: Favorite Sushi in SF! You can't go wrong with the flaming sushi and the Ya Man role. There are a couple cute wine bars nearby as well if there's a wait for a table. Love love love this place.
author: Ariella B.

description:
Came here in a Sunday afternoon with a group of 4. Only had to wait 20 minutes which was a plus. 

First of the inside is definitely cozy and dark . Surely a great a place for a date. Intimate and trendy.

2$ sake bombs during happy are a deal . Not sure where else you can find such a deal in SF

The flaming roll was on point, definitely deserves the great reputation it has . It is literally set on fire. Really filling too.

Rainbow roll tasted fresh but in many ways similar to other rainbow rolls .

Godzilla roll was super unique. Really melts in your mouth wish there was more.

Overall great experience and glad I didn't have to really wait in line. Pricey but could be worse for sushi . Nonetheless did feel a bit rushed to leave because they were trying to cycle new people in . Guess it comes with the environment
author: Pat C.

description:
My favorite restaurant so far since I've moved to SF! It was highly recommended and I was worried it would be over-hyped,  but not to fear -- I loved everything I got! 

Definitely come early-- I walked in at about 6:05 on a Wednesday and it was already filling up. I got a seat at the sushi bar and ordered 2 rolls and an order of Sake sushi. 

The flaming sea bass is a must-get: not exactly traditional flavors, but extremely tasty, and a fun dish to get! Also got the Red & Yellow roll which was just excellent.

The salmon sushi was incredibly fresh and had the perfect texture. 

Service was quite friendly and it was fun sitting at the bar and getting to watch the sushi chefs at work. 

I will definitely be frequenting this place as long as I am in the area!
author: Abby B.

description: Great sushi... my go to! No reservations and they won't sit you until your party is there.... totally worth it!!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
So good. 

I missed the first 6pm seating so my fiance and I ended up waiting around 30-45 minutes.

Is it worth a 30-45 minute wait? I think so. 2 hours? Maybe not. To kill time, we hopped on over to Swensen's across the street. The waitress even gave us hot tea to sip on while we waited on a chilly evening, which was a really sweet gesture.

I saw tables of 4+ being quoted 2-3 hours around 6:30pm, but tables of two didn't have to wait more than one hour -- something to keep in mind if you're planning to come in with a larger group.

Once we sat down, we immediately ordered the White Out roll, Ya Man roll, yummy pocket, Himalayan trout, and sizzling sea bass. Of all the items, the white out roll was my favorite. The sizzling sea bass is fun to watch (who doesn't like fire?), but it honestly was kind of bland and didn't blow my mind. I don't think I would order it again. However, everything else was fresh and tasty.

Note to self: If (WHEN) I go back to Elephant Sushi, I'll load up on the rolls. I'll come well before 6pm to snag a table. And I'll drink some sake bombs because they're only $2.
author: Valerie L.

description:
It is absolutely 1000000% worth the wait! Then again we came on a Wednesday night at 8:06pm and was quoted only a 1 hour wait, which miraculously worked out to be exactly an hour. The hostess does an amazing job in getting down names, bussing tables, and trying to be realistic about the wait but just be prepared that it could take longer...but it's worth it!

#1 absolutely get the assorted sashimi platter. There's no frills & no imitation crab bullshit; it is straight up perfect size pieces of fresh fish.  They gave us fatty tuna, butter fish, yellow tail, & trout. They were all buttery and amazing!!!!! 

#2 I loved the chips & dip. It was a great starter & the amount of fish is generous!

#3 the flaming sea bass isn't gimmicky. It's baked, absolutely flavorful & everyone orders it so instead of staring just order your own; you won't go wrong.  

#4 if you're an uni fan (ie butter of the sea) the uni nigiri and the beastie boys are an absolute. The nigiri is fresh fresh uni. The beastie boy is a creative twist. My husband said it was breakfast in his mouth once the yolk broke. I sadly tasted more rice so basically you need to be strategic in how to eat it.

#5 the service is efficient and great! It's as if they haven't described what they're going to do with the flaming sea bass a thousand times earlier in the night. 

#6 their bottle of Sauvignon Blanc is blan so opt for a different wine or beverage. 

Bottom line. Go! Get there before the doors open at 6pm to put your name down for that night and again get the assorted sashimi platter for sure!! And don't overlook their homemade pickled ginger which is awesome!!
author: Jenny K. L.

description:
OK, my credentials up front.  Not to brag, just to bring some perspective.
15 years living in Japan, eating raw fish almost 24/7.
I'm a sushi freak, but not a snob. 

So when you have a Yelper saying, "You won't find fresher fish anywhere." (I won't mention any names.) You have to realize that maybe that Yelper just got introduced to sushi recently. And to him or her, Elephant Sushi *is* the best fish that he/she has ever put in his/her mouth .

Contrast that with someone like me, who has been eating sushi in the Land of the Rising Sun since the early 80's.  Again, not to brag, but just to make the point, it makes a big difference to know the background and experience of a food reviewer before you swallow hook, line and sinker.  That goes for all food, not just sushi.  Experience counts when you're looking for an opinion. Just sayin.  

My daughter was born in Japan and knows her sushi stuff pretty well too.  She was with us at Elephant and made this comment about their fish:

"Dad, they don't know how to cut fish here."

She was right.  The way they cut the fish at Elephant was not maximizing the taste and texture of the fish (I have also worked at a sushi bar.)

We were very lucky to be seated as walk-ins.  Hostess said it was very rare.  We were an odd 3 people and they had a spot that worked for only us in the line.

Here's what we ordered:

YELLOW FIN BITES (3/5)  Not bad, not good, just middle of the road.

HAMACHI W/TRUFFLE  (4/5)  Probably the best of the bunch.  It had garlic chips and green onion.  It was a good twist on the usual trendy thing they're doing these days adding the jalapeño. I think Nobu in LA originated the hamachi/jalapeno combo.

YA MAN ROLL (3/5)  Salmon cut a bit too thick for me.  But I liked the concept of red onion chips and pesto thrown in for good measure.  Still, flavors got too busy for me and the fish was no longer the star of the show.

We also had an assortment of nigiri which included:  MAGURO, HAMACHI, SALMON AND WALU (which is the Hawaiian word for ESCOLAR) which is basically a kind of tuna.  Different sushi places will call fish by different names and it can be confusing.  What is even more confusing is when sushi restaurants will mislabel their fish (sometimes deliberately and sometimes ignorantly) depending on the fish and how they want to market it to the customer. For example, some sushi chef might think it's more appealing to call it "butterfish"rather than its common name "escolar".  If I were a sushi chef, I think I'd opt to call it "butterfish" too just because it sounds more appetizing than the former.  Let's not forget too that some chefs will deliberately (and fraudulently) call a cheap fish by a different name just to make it sound expensive.  Wow, I got off on a tangent here.

Anyway, I think there's def some hype going on here with ES.  I think, if you're not a spoiled sushi eater, you're likely to have a good experience here.  But if you've been around the block in terms of sushi-eating experience, then I would say you're not going to find your happy face here.

I haven't been there in a long time, but look up KABUTO restaurant for some off-the-chart sushi goodness.  And if you're in the LA area, look up SUGARFISH.  SUGARFISH is completely affordable and unbelievably delicious.
author: Darien R.

description: The best sushi in the city, relaxed vibe, great service, love everything about this place. It's worth the wait!
author: Allie F.

description:
We came 15m before 6pm (when they open) thinking there was going to be a huge wait on a Saturday night. There was only 3 people in front of us but definitely had more people lined up, but not as busy as some of the reviews made it seem. 

Food: we ordered the Ya Man Roll, Flaming Sea Bass, Beastie Boys, and White Out Roll. All were extremely tasty and fresh. The Flaming Sea Bass was set on fire so it's a fun experience while having dinner. The Beastie Boys was a new experience since I've never had quail eggs and sea urchin. 

Service: the server was extremely nice and recommended the White Out Roll (great recommendation). 

The only downside was the sun directly in my eyes the entire time (they obviously can't control the sun) so try to get a table away from the door. That would also make the flames on the sea bass look cooler for a photo op!
author: Anna L.

description:
$2 sake bombs in Russian Hill - who would have known! 

Well I finally made it to Elephant Sushi after having a friend rave about this place for months. We luckily stopped by around 5 and a waitress was outside taking reservations for 6. We snagged the last table for 4. Be warned, this place is tiny! And all the tables are really meant for 2 people. So this is not the place to come with a group. The owner has a 4 people max policy. 

The sushi rolls on the menu were certainly unique compared to other spots in the city. I loved the flaming sea bass roll - to the point that i was scrubbing the rice of the foil. The white out roll was good, but certainly overhyped. We also really liked the red and yellow roll. After a few sake bombs, we started getting more hungry, and asked the waitress for a recommendation. She said to try the roll with the banana in it - sushi with banana sounded real weird but we decided it was worth a shot. And the roll turned out to actually taste pretty good, but not one I would get again.

Overall, I would come back, the $2 sake bombs really make this place appealing.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Overrated and overpriced.

One thing was amazing, the simple garden salad. Tossed with fresh salmon and tuna highly recommend.

Unfortunately the roles did "too much" - flaming Seabass was over cooked which made the tuna very fishy. The salmon roll with pesto mixed weird flavors resulting in a mustard like taste.

If you want to pay $20 a dish for not great sushi, go for it. I'd never go back but the vibe is cool hence he hype and positive reviews.
author: Jessica M.

description: The sushi is amazing. We were very pleased with the ya-man roll! Ambiance is great. Would be an awesome place for a date.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Went there last night since its so close to my home and ordered omakase. 

I just came back from Japan 2 weeks ago and the taste of Japanese sushi is still in my memory.

This place has attentive service, good quality fish and happy customers. Made few friends while eating at the sushi bar. Loved it!
author: Anelya S.

description:
Coming here was worth the hike. If you're coming from Van Ness, you'll have to climb up two hills to get here. I tried dining here a few months back, but gave up after driving around in circles trying to find parking. The restaurant is very small. Most of the tables can only fit two people. There's a long wait, but you can check out the shops and bars nearby until they call you.

Started off with the Beastie Boys - uni, quail egg, ankimo and shiso. I highly recommend this. It's a party in your mouth. Also had their naked scallop roll. They wrap it in soy paper which gives it a nuttier taste.

The service was efficient which makes up for the wait. What sets this place apart from other sushi restaurants is their homemade ginger. They make their ginger in house and they serve it in a glass jar with tongs. It's thicker, crunchier and not as sweet as the artificial ones.
I'll have to come back here for the flaming sea bass.
author: Helen C.

description:
What we ordered
1. Himalayan trout
2. Flaming sea bass roll 
3. Ya man roll
4. Hello Kitty Martinis $5

Total bill ~$75

Service: Fantastic, we were seated fast but could tell there is a long wait here. They take reservations. Great for dates. 

Ambiance: Dark with candles. Small and intimate

Loved it I will def be coming back!!!
author: Joy M.

description:
After looking for a sushi restaurant in San Francisco on Yelp I decided on Elephant Sushi as it looked like the type of place that we would enjoy. I was right!!

Elephant Sushi is not your grandmother's sushi restaurant. It is a small place with a great vibe and a menu full of original sushi creations. As you read the descriptions on the menu each one sounds better than the last, which makes it difficult to decide on what to order. 

In the end we settled on: the Hawaiian Poki salad, Yummy Pockets, Chips and Dip, Blue Fin Bites and Godzilla. The items are as creative as the names would suggest. All the ingredient were extremely fresh and delicious and it wold be a challenge to decide on a favorite. 

Given the quality of the food the prices are very reasonable and the portions extremely generous. After the first 3 dishes were delivered to our table I began to worry that we may struggle to finish everything that we ordered because the portion were so substantial. Luckily this challenge was overcome by how tasty everything was and we managed to polish it all off. Unfortunately we were only two people so we only had a chance to sample a portion of the menu and there are so many other great items that we didn't get to try. I will definitely be back, if not during this trio to San Francisco on my next.
author: Rod M.

description:
A bit overhyped IMO for the 1 hr wait, price, and food. My boyfriend and I ordered the seared hamachi w/ truffle sauce,the ya man roll, and the flaming sea bass.

Hamachi Truffle: I might be a bit biased since I don't like yellowtail but I thought this dish was just okay and really pricey. My bf liked it though.

Ya Man Roll: My favorite! The salmon was so buttery and fresh. I would highly recommend getting this.

Flaming Sea Bass: This is one of those dishes that your order for photos. It looks pretty cool since it comes lit on fire, but was drenched so heavily in sauce that I really disliked it; the sushi rice got pretty mushy. This roll also requires time to cook in the fire, so we ended up waiting a quite some time before we could finally eat it. 

Overall fresh fish but very catered towards those who like japanese/american fusion rolls. Since my taste bud is on the lighter side, I don't think I enjoyed the food here as much as others would.
author: Sophia H.

description:
First off - $$ is a lie. Dishes average $20/each and you need between 5-7 for two people. 

Second - customer service not only does not exist, but they have the balls to provide 3 tips levels on the bill - 20%, 25%, 30%. Just plain obnoxious. The place is overpriced as is. 

Fish - Some dishes were very tasty -- trout! Others not so much: Hamachi Truffle was overpowered with fired onions, all I tasted were onions. The double albacore roll is just a ball of mush. No texture, no crunch, just mush. 

Yet another overpriced establishment for all the over paid folk who don't know much about good food.
author: Howard G.

description: This has become my favorite salmon sashimi place. We enjoyed it so much the first tine, we ordered a second one at the end. Their iconic flaming sea bass is also out of this world. We also loved the boom box :) If you like sushi, this is the place for you!
author: Fanny T.

description: Very rude and has a nasty attitude with their employees and customers. Food had hair in it. Don't waste your time coming here.
author: Mary A.

description: Took my cousin's kid here during her visit to SF and it was a big hit for everyone. We ordered mostly sashimi and it was very fresh. Highly recommended is the uni, hamachi truffle and the albacore tataki. Not recommended was the flaming seabass...it's a whole lot of flashy preparation but lacks on flavor delivery. I will also be coming back for the $5 hello kitty martinis.
author: Mai C.

description:
We ordered the omakase sashimi, and the pieces were beautifully cut.  The salmon, tuna and amber jack were perfect in texture and taste.  The "Himalayan" ocean trout sashimi was amazing as well.

We tried some rolls too- they were okay (too much rice and filler).  They also need a bigger sake selection.  But I'll be back just for the sashimi.
author: Rego S.

description: The wait was definitely longer than quoted, but we went to a great wine bar across the street and enjoyed ourselves. Even if we had to wait without wine, it would have totally been worth it. This sushi is incredible! I will say the Nigiri is better than the rolls so if you're into Nigiri stick to that portion of the menu and you won't be disappointed. Each piece is really generous, I know you're supposed to eat in all in one bite but it was so large that I had to take two (the hubs made it work with one bite of course). His favorite was the Beastie boy, a unique mixture of quail egg, Sea Urchin and several other yummy ingredients. The Himalayan Trout appetizer was my personal favorite. It was served on a salt block and it was the perfect balance of fish with a tiny layer of salt on top. We also got the Flaming Sea Bass roll which is super cool to watch cook, but we both agreed that the fish was too cooked at the end and we would probably have preferred it raw. All in all, the best sushi I've ever had and we will return!
author: Cambria N.

description:
This place has been on my list since it opened and I finally got to go last night! It totally exceeded my expectations and I'm already planning on going back soon!

Arrived around 6:20 to three open tables. The hostess said I couldn't get seated until my entire party (my boyfriend who was parking) had arrived so she took my name down. In the 20 minute it took him to find parking, about ten other people had arrived so there went our no wait! The hostess was very sweet and sympathetic and assured me a table would be opening up soon and we only and to wait another ten minutes once my bf had arrived. 

If you have an option to choose, try to sit against the wall and not near the entry way because it ended up getting packed with people! I had time to look at the menu while I was waiting and I was shocked at the $2 sake bomb. WTF $2! That is the cheapest drink I've ever seen in SF and was amazed not every single table was doing sake bombs! Well my bf and I ended up not doing it because he's stopped drinking beer and I opted for the Hello Kitty martini instead at the very low price of $5. A table behind us ordered sake bombs and got one for the waiter and we watched them down it all. Loved it! Our waiter was AMAZING and he was able to just memorize our entire order. What a pro!

I wanted to get the sea bass that most people had at their table but was put off by the $16 price tag since it was just one roll! Definitely coming back and ordering it tho. We ended up ordering the Yummy Pocket, Hotate Nigiri, Giant's Roll, and the Spicy Hamachi Roll. The Hamachi roll was my least favorite. The scallop nigiri tasted way different than any other scallops I've ever had and I'm not sure why. Either it was amazing or it was not fresh but since I can't tell I'll just go with amazing. The yummy pocket was super cute and I usually never eat those rice filled tofu skins but its another story when its topped with spicy scallops! 

Disappointed there was no toro or fish specials. Also I love ginger and was really excited to see they made their own and it was awful. I really did not like it at all and kind of just forced myself to eat it between bites as a palette cleanser. Sorry I guess I like my ginger marinated in sugar! 

Impressed with the $40 bill at the end including my martini especially since we had a very mediocre $70 sushi meal somewhere in Rockridge and we didn't even order any alcohol and left still hungry. For the quality of Elephant sushi the price is ridic! They could easily charge double and people wouldn't blink an eye but I think its one of the reasons why its so popular. Can't wait to come back!
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Absolutely delicious! Came here twice and with both times, I unfortunately had to wait more than an hour (ugh, boooo...!!!). Although their food is fantastic, I'm not quite sure if I would [want to] wait for that long again.. 

MUST TRIES: 
- For starters: I loved both the hamachi truffle and walu corpaccio. Of the two, I preferred the hamachi truffle but both were yummy.
- White out roll: seriously, this roll is amazing!! Hamachi and avocado inside, with seared butter fish on top with an overall scrumptious flavor from the garlic ponzu. Must must muuuust get this!
- Flaming seabass roll: I feel this roll is more for the cool wow factor experience of a flaming skinny-burrito-lookin' thing on your table. With most baked rolls, the taste of the fish is often hidden by all of the sauces. I couldn't tell there was sea bass or or tuna in there. Regardless, the roll was very smooth and bursting with flavors! It was different, filling and delicious.

Ya man roll was great too (salmon, avocado, pesto & ponzu sauce), and their sake nigiri was fresh and buttery.

I would personally pass on the naked scallop roll and spicy hamachi roll, but if that looks and sounds delicious for your tastebuds, then go for it! They weren't bad at all - I just didn't think they were anything special and wouldn't order them again.

Fish tasted and felt extremely fresh. It's a little pricier here, but given the location, quality of food and unique take on sushi, I guess that's understandable. Most of the tables are situated very close together. Service is prompt and waitresses can easily be flagged down. If you're able to dodge (or you don't mind) the 1+ hour wait, then go for it!!! Parking is a pain in the ass in this area, so good luck with that! I've seen a lot of people take uber or lyft here, so that's something to consider!
author: Kris C.

description: The atmosphere of the restaurant and the service is great. The sushi rolls here are creative. With that said, the flavor combinations are a hit or miss.
author: Debbie I.

description: Tasty sushi and not too crowded at 8:30 pm on a Saturday night. Lots of non-traditional sushi options, so stay clear if you're a Japanese food puritan!
author: Kaitlyn C.

description:
I can't even begin to describe the experience we just had at Elephant Sushi. We just moved to Russian Hill, and were excited to check out our local sushi spot. 

Upon arrival, our waitress forgot absolutely everything that we ordered. We had to check in with her multiple times before she got our order right. 

When our friends chair BROKE INTO PIECES, they acted like absolutely nothing happened. Replacing the chair within moments, as though this happens regularly, not even asking him if he was okay. Not one apology was expressed. Not one. 

The night was almost over, and we tried to pay our bill. They wouldn't let us split between cards, fine. We asked for a discount at this point. The servers had to ask their manager, as he stands in front of our table saying "fuck no, fuck no." He sees us overhearing this, and gives us a condescending smile and wive. 

We finally pay our bill. And tip, of course. We walk outside and two managers are harassing our friend that fell, luckily unharmed, out of their chair. They aggressively attacked him with: "Are you a man bro? Did you break our chair bro?!" We told them we wouldn't return any business back to them, and they say "Good, don't come back," while they laughed. 

Upon getting in my taxi, I told them I was planning to leave a Yelp review. He screamed "FUCK YOU!" with the middle finger while choking down a cigarette. 

Clearly some entitled asian mafia scary awful people who don't need one penny of business. So sad - we were looking forward to spending many fun nights at this local sushi spot. Do yourself a favor, spend your money on some hard working, honest people who value you business. 

Wow.
author: Haley B.

description:
While this is not a traditional sushi restaurant, the flavor combinations here are sure to pack a punch. The hamachi truffle was as expected...truffly.  It was tasty but not sure the small plate was wroth $25.  The star of the night was definitely the flaming sea bass.  The sushi comes wrapped in foil over a bowl of what I'm assuming is alcohol.  The servers light the bowl so that the flames cook the sushi for about 8 minutes.  Don't worry, a server will come back to put out the flame and unwrap the sushi when it's ready.  It was extremely flavorful and unlike any other sushi experience I've ever had.  Again, definitely far from traditional, but if you're into that, this is a must order! 

The restaurant is quite small so I wouldn't recommend groups of more than 4. Even with two, the tables are small and close together.
author: Melissa T.

description:
This is possibly one of the BEST Sushi joints we've eaten at to date. I can also declare that this is probably one of the better (if not the BEST) Sushi joints in San Franciso. 

I took the Wifey here for her birthday dinner and I quickly realized that I should have made a reservation. In my defense, she picked me up from work and wanted to go out for dinner and my birthday plans for her was for the next day. Yeah...no excuses.  

It was a Friday evening, May 9th to be exact and the wind was biting; typical San Francisco weather and the line was out the door. The wait was over an hour and a half, but it didn't faze the Wifey. Parking is also a pain, but I don't care. I ended up parking four blocks away. Take note that the Cable Car runs in front of the place for those of you who are not willing to drive and battle traffic.

While we were waiting, we were scrolling at the food pics, which made us hungrier and hungrier. By the time our name was called, it was under an hour a half wait but over an hour, and it was totally worth the wait. 

We sat at the Sushi Bar and we got the coolest, laid-back and friendliest server we've ever encountered. I forgot his name, but he had long, curly hair and had that Japanese Surfer vibe to him. Told him it was the Wifey's birthday and he got her a free drink; it was a Hello Kitty Martini. 

The Sushi Chef then gave us two pieces of Butterfish Sashimi as a FREE appetizer. Not only was it FREE, but it was HELLA good. It was well-balanced dish from taste to contrasting texture. It was so clean and fresh and the Fried Garlic Chips added a level of contrast and taste that made me do the happy dance. I knew that we were in for a treat. 

Based on Ethan Z's reviews, who was the first Yelper that highly recommended this place to us, we ordered the following:

Flaming Seabass - Sushi roll served in a foil cooked in flame on your table
Himalayan Trout - New Zealand Ocean Trout cured on a Himalayan Rock Salt
Ya Man Roll - King Salmon, Avocado, Scallion, Fried Red Onion Chips, Pesto and Ponzu
Boom Box - Japanese Spicy Scallops, Avocado, Garlic Chips, Cucumber wrapped in Banana
Rainbow Roll - Assorted Fresh Fish
Beastie Boys - Uni, Ankimo (Monkfish Liver), Quail Eggs and Shiso Leaf

The Boom Box was a surprise since who would have thought banana wouldn't go together with scallops, let alone mixing it as a sushi ingredient? It wasn't too sweet, but the contrast of sweet and spicy was at work again balancing it off. 

The Himalayan Trout was on a bed of rock salt that was seasoned lightly with sea salt. You didn't need to add soy sauce to add some flavor as the dishes were left shining on their own with the high level of freshenss and quality. This was also true for the Ya Man Roll.
