There was a nice theme of contrasting flavor and texture that were nicely married to form a union. 

For the Flaming Seabass, you had to wait a while until it's cooked and had to time it precisely in order to get the best experience. Our server told us exactly when to eat it as it was still hot and told us not to let it cool off. I love how some of the rice became crunchy and I was happily digging them from the foil and popping them straight to our mouth. 

And for the Rainbow Roll, there's nothing more to add except to say that everyhing was fresh. This would be a great roll by itself if served in other sushi joints, 

As for the Beastie Boys....I saved the BEST for last. I can honestly say that this was the BEST sushi I've ever placed in my mouth. The combination of Uni, Monkfish Liver, Quail Egg and Shiso Leaf was a delectable experience that hit my tastebuds like a frontal assault of umami goodness. It was silky, creamy and smooth and went down like the finest vintage wine that's over a hundred years old. 

WOW, simply amazing experience.

I know where I'll be eating on my birthday.
author: John G.

description:
No doubt this has been the best sushi I've ever eaten! Usually sushi restaurants have pages and pages of rolls. Elephant sushi only had one page of rolls which kind of threw me off in the beginning. We saw the boom box roll which had ripe banana and wanted to try it so bad even though it sounded so weird! IT WAS SO GOOD! Nothing like I've ever had but it tasted perfect. 

Then we asked the waitress what the most popular roll was and she advised us to get the sea bass roll. It came out in flames and the finished product was absolutely amazing.

They also have happy hour ALL NIGHT! We first got a hello kitty martini which was delicious and only $5! Then we each got a sake bomb which I don't usually like but these were delicious and only $2!!! 

They told us it was going to be an hour wait but we only waited 20 minutes for the two of us! So great, you need to go there!
author: Rima B.

description:
This place is AMAAAZING! 

But before I go into the food, there are some tips you need to know.

#1 - since it opens at 6pm (and you don't already have a dinner reservation). GET THERE EARLY, around 15-30 min earlier, if you want to be seated as soon as they open. They don't have a list but usually the people waiting go by the honor system, which is great! Or else you'll be waiting for a while, and I mean a while. 

#2 - parties are LIMITED TO 4 MAX! Make it a date, bring another friend or two. But no more than that. 

Food:

Hands down, you must try the WHITE OUT ROLL (if you love raw fish). It's freaking de-licious! The fish feels like it melts in your mouth. No sauce needed for this bad boy. 

$2 sake bombs for happy hour! What a deal! Great when paired with the sushi.

Can't wait to go back already!
author: Christine N.

description:
Hamachi Truffle - 4.5 stars (must order) 
Flaming Sea Bass - 4 stars (taste similar to the Lion King Roll) 
Beastie Boys - 2.5 stars 
$2 sake bombs - 5 stars!!

I was a bit disappointed by the Beastie Boys since I read from so many yelpers that it was an amazing roll.  I was expecting a life changing moment, but my boyfriend and I just didn't like it so much. Maybe we aren't much uni lovers as others, but it wasn't anything special to me. 

Hamachi truffle on the other hand, that was a delicate dish.  It was enough to make me close my eyes to taste the different flavors the truffle, garlic, soy sauce, and fresh hamachi. Definitely recommend it.

$2 sake bomb on a Saturday night was AWESOME. 45 minute wait wasn't so much, but we went down to Leopold's down the street to grab a beer and that place was also awesome!! So we had a great night in Russian Hill :)
author: Raquel Y.

description:
What a unique put and gourmet twist to sushi and sashimi!

I absolutely loved the Flaming Seabass Sushi Roll for its flaring presentation!  The entree was geared towards a cooked, sticky rice and saucy type of sushi roll wrapped in a flaming foil compared to the standard cold sushi rolls!  

Do get their Himalayan Trout on an iced salt rock!  The light, salty blend and smooth sashimi texture that was topped with saffron, tasted marvelous!  You don't need the wasabi and soy sauce to enjoy this!  It's simplicity at its finest!

I also admired the Truffle Hamachi, aplenty!  The truffle piece, enhanced the flavor of the hamachi sashimi!  It was delightfully enjoyable!  

Get this!  It's 2 bucks for sake bombs!  Time to drink up! 

With a cozy and dimly lit setting, I do recommend coming here with a reservation or only during non-peak dining hours!  It's a small place, but permissibly worthwhile!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Best sushi I've had in San Francisco!! 

I arrived here on Friday night 10 till 6 and there was a decently long line outside the front door already! After quickly getting in line I was surprised by the fact that my two friends and I actually got a table and didn't even have to wait! (we really just got fortunate; were the last group to be seated before the wait began)

I ordered the Ya Man roll and we all split a large hot sake. The roll was DELICIOUS! the onions on the inside really make the roll extra special. The salmon was perfect and there were just enough green onions to add a nice balance of flavor. Paired with their super fresh spicy ginger...and OMG literal sushi heaven. 

I would 100% recommend this place; the price, quality, and atmosphere are impossible to beat. 5 stars STRONG :)
author: Katie 2.

description: The sashimi was great - we got the 16 piece omakazi. They put seasoning on some of the pieces which we didn't like but loved some of the pieces without seasoning. We got the roll that they light on fire- it was fun and it tasted great. We also got the white out roll which I hated and couldn't even eat (I've never not liked a sushi roll but maybe I just got unlucky). There's a bit of a wait but the service is good once you're seated!
author: Susannah H.

description:
By far one of the best sushi establishments I've been to. I really like their menu and how short and to the point it is: sashimi, nigiri and rolls. Ordered 5 things from the menu and each was absolutely excellent. The fish literally melts in your mouth. 
Himalayan trout on salt slab, bass, butterfish, flaming roll, and the scallop pockets. Yum!
author: Jennifer Y.

description: WOW...WOW...WOW!!!  The food is worth the wait!  Amazing is an understatement!  You have to have the Flaming Seabass!  Incredible!!!!
author: Ruben H.

description:
Personally, one of the best sushi spot in the city. The staff there are really nice and hospitable. Wait time without a reservation on a weekday was around 15 mins but they do call you to let you know when the table is ready while you stroll around the bars nearby! (:
Loved the flaming seabass and the giants roll.
I'd eat here everyday if I could. Plus, who'd say no to the $2 sake bombs!
author: Rose G.

description:
I have never, and I mean never, dealt with such snobbery at a restaurant before. To put it plainly - Elephant Sushi is the type of restaurant that gives SF a bad name.

Yes, I've eaten here before. And yes, the sushi is good. It's not amazing, but it's definitely worth a visit...if the employees weren't so awful to interact with.

The service once you're seated is okay. The place is always super crowded, very VERY loud and not exactly nice, but for a "hole-in-the-wall" sushi place it does just fine. The main issue is that the employees who work on giving wait times are awful. If they're taking names at all - yup, they stop taking names around 7:30 pm most nights - they will quote 2-3 hours no matter what. I've had that quote, left after putting my name in, and been called between half an hour and an hour. It has never been even close to 2-3 hours, and I have no idea why they consistently lie about that. 

Like I said, they stop taking names super early every night. They'll claim they're full and can't take any more people, but then if you show up a few hours later they'll be glad to seat you. I'm not kidding, I have seen this happen countless times. I've had friends who show up later and are seated when hours prior I'd been told "no more tonight, sorry."

Also, I stopped in well before close on a weekday and was told they were sold out of fish. It was still over an hour until close, tons of empty tables, and clearly pounds and pounds of fish behind the counter. I kid you not, they told me they couldn't seat me because they were "totally out of fish."

I only stop by so often because I live nearby. I will never, ever try to eat here again and recommend you do the same. I simply cannot support an establishment that treats customers the way Elephant does, and there are plenty of awesome sushi places in the city that don't do that. Shame on you, Elephant.
author: Nicole H.

description:
You must try this restaurant!

Stumbled upon this place on Yelp while driving to San Fran from the airport. Saw the great reviews and decided to walk into the place. We have a wait of about 40 minutes (on a Thursday Night - good sign). We decided to take the wait and go to the near by wine bar while time passes.

When we finally got seated the food was incredible and so was the service. Our waitress was very helpful in making food choices, explaining everything well. She was also perfectly attentive during the meal.

Must try flaming sea bass. Incredible.. They serve the roll wrapped in foil, in a bowl full of fire. From the presentation to the mousewatering taste, everying was impressive.

Ya mon is also absolutely delicious.

We also ordered some fresh salmon, and tuna. The fish was sooo fresh. Omg the salmon was sooooo succulent.

If you are a local or an out of towner, Elephant Sushi is a must try place!
author: Nataliya A.

description: I came for dinner here with my husband. At first by the look of the patio i thought "maybe I am overdressed" but once you walk in it was a different feel so I'm glad my outfit was ok. Service was great, along with the rolls and nigiri! Would I come back? Yes and have more of their warm peanuts!
author: Natalie S.

description:
It makes me sad to have to write this review but I don't want my friends to come here thinking this is still my favorite sushi place in SF D: 

I finally came back here for a second visit last night and my bf and I were super excited since we remembered how good everything was last time we were here. The wait for 2 people was around 30-45 minutes and we overheard the wait being 2hrs for groups bigger than 2. They take down your phone number and call when the seats are ready so you can spend time exploring the area instead of having to wait there.

We got seated at the bar so we could see all the sushi making action up close. Since we loved them last time, we ordered the Himalayan Sea Salt Trout and White Out Roll again. For our new dishes, we got the Fatty Tuna appetizer, Uni nigiri, and Walu nigiri. The only thing we loved was the trout :( The white out roll was good but not as flavorful as we remembered. There was too much avocado in the roll and it overpowered the fish. They were out of toro for the fatty tuna dish so the chef told us he would use chu toro instead. When he served it to us, he said it would be chewy but taste very good. Well it tasted okay but it was a lot chewier than other times we've had it so we were very disappointed :( The walu nigiri was good, the seasoning on top was lemon pepper I think? For the uni, he gave us a huge portion so I was excited for that but it was also just okay and there was a slight weird aftertaste to it :(

Since we were sitting right in front of the chef we didn't really voice our disappointment to each other during the meal. Once we left though, we both immediately were like.. that was NOT as good as last time! The only dish that was like "oo this is so good" was the sea salt trout. Everything else was "meh". Not sure what happened to this place but I guess we will be looking for another fav sushi joint in the city :/
author: Sandra N.

description: I loved the flaming sea bass and $2 sake bombs but it was so not worth a 1+ hour wait. The Godzilla was good but small and something you could get at any other sushi place. Save yourself the trouble.
author: Jane H.

description:
I don't give out a lot of five stars, but this place is pretty incredible. Be prepared to wait, we put our names down for table of 2 (called earlier, but they only took walk-ins and you had to sign-in in person) around 7pm on Saturday and waited around 45 minutes. The restaurant is small, but the tables are spaced in a way that you don't feel like the next table is sitting on your lap. The wait staff is genuinely friendly and not snobby, which can be rare in popular restaurants.

Onto the food -- while we were waiting, we saw a flaming roll on every table (the flaming sea bass), so we thought we should definitely give it a try. We also ordered the beastie boys (negiri of uni, monkfish liver and raw quail egg) and the spicy hamachi.

Our waitress brought us a sample of two slices of barely seared butterfish with a truffle oil and ponzu sauce topped with fried onions. I've never had butterfish, and wow, where have you been all my life?! The fish tasted so fresh and is soft and just melted in my mouth. There was only a hint of truffle oil, so not to overwhelm the other flavors. Definitely 10/10! A very promising start of our dinner.

Next up we got the spicy hamachi and the beastie boys. The hamachi actually wasn't spicy (it's supposed to have some jalapenos), but the fish was so fresh. There was a bit of ponzu that added some acidity and the avocado gave it more creaminess. There was a bit of cucumber for crunch to complete the roll. There were 8 pieces in the roll and it was a fattie. I like a bit more texture to rice in sushi rolls and the rice was slightly on the mushy side, so I gave it 8/5/10. 

The beastie boys, in my opinion, is the best bite in SF. It's even better than the Scotched eggs from the Cavalier, and that's saying a lot. You gotta eat the whole thing in one bite. I don't think I ever had monk fish liver before and the flavor reminds me a bit of foie gras. It was rich, firm (but not hard) and creamy. The sea urchin was sweet and just a bit of brininess, very fresh. The quail egg yoke added more richness to the dish. IT'S A MUST ORDER!!

The flaming sea bass was roasting over the bowl for around 8 minutes. Our waitress helped us open it up and plate it after the flame went out. It's kind of like the lion king roll, I think. I thought it was too much teriyaki that overpowered the fish. It just tasted like a dollop of teriyaki sauce over rice. I couldn't taste the fish at all. 

All in all, we loved our experience and hope to be back soon. The staff is so friendly, always a smile and the food is just amazing. Great spot :).
author: Alice W.

description: Amazing sushi, great service and ambiance. Perfect for date night or girls' night! Excited to go back. The flaming eel roll was delicious as well as an experience to watch them prepare it (aka set it on fire right at your table).
author: Michelle H.

description: I actually liked the food, the service was pleasant, but the poor health inspection score will keep me from returning!
author: Bogee B.

description:
I think this is definitely going to be another go-to favorite of mine. Really digging that clunk of salt they put the sashimi in. Sashimi and fish in rolls were super fresh. Snapchat worthy, it's a must! 

FYI, wait will be at least 1-hour long!
author: Joyce L.

description:
We got here at 8:30 on a Sunday night for dinner and didn't have to wait at all. We trekked through a couple of intense hills just to dine here, so by the time we arrived, we were ready to eat everything. Unfortunately, that would not have been good for our wallet, so we settled on 4 sushi rolls. 

We got the flaming sea bass roll, the spicy hamachi roll, the Giants roll and the spicy tuna. Honestly, I wasn't a big fan of the Giants roll because it had tomatoes, which didn't go well with sushi. I'm not a big fan of raw tomatoes, but my boyfriend loved it. The hamachi and spicy tuna were delicious, but those are the most basic sushi rolls so it's difficult to mess them up. The flaming sea bass roll was the highlight of the meal. They presented the roll wrapped in aluminum foil and placed it on top of a burning plate for 8-9 minutes. I wonder if anyone ever got hurt while ordering the sea bass because the flame got pretty wild. The presentation was really unique but the roll itself was dumped in sauce so that made it break apart easily. Real sushi is not supposed to break apart!  

Overall, great service and decent ambiance. My total bill came out to $60 for 2 people so it's not too bad. I'm not sure if I would ever make the trek up here again, but if I do, I would definitely order the sashimi salad because that looked bomb. FYI - this place is closed on Monday and Tuesday.
author: Joyce S.

description: Wanted to like this place so bad. I live up the street. This place smells of rotten fish. The rolls primarily consist of al dente rice and fish you'd expect to be served inland. The cramped tables are packed with bros in puffer vests embroidered with tech logos and women in ill fitting active wear. The staff is unexpectedly uppity given the services they don't provide. Hah. Anyone who waits in line for this is a chump.
author: Zoe P.

description: Came here on our last night in San Fran and it did not disappoint! We arrived early 5:45 and there were already people ahead of us waiting. We ordered the albacore tuna on the salt block- AMAZING!! Melt in your mouth, great flavor. Ordered 3 rolls ( Giants, spicy hamachi and a scallop roll) all excellent! Also, ordered lots of nigiri and let me tell you- the best I've ever had. Tuna, salmon w pesto, sea bass, hamachi. So so good! Fresh, flavorful, just the right thickness. The staff was super friendly and we loved the intimate vibe. Not to mention, the music was on point. We will definitely return on our next trip to San Fran! Don't pass up this small sushi joint!
author: Jessica S.

description:
Love the sushi, but have to give a low score based on the accommodations of the restaurant.  

We had my wife's sister, husband and two kids in town and wanted to go to a good sushi dinner.  We arrived 15 mins before opening and asked to get a party of 6.  The restaurant does not do parties of more than 4 (understandable), so we asked to do a 4 top and a 2 top with two separate checks. 

The only way they would accept that is if the sat the two tables on opposite sides of the restaurant.  

A very strange rule and does not seem to be a customer focused attitude.  Oh well.

If you want good sushi and have a small party, target this place.  Otherwise, hit one of the other top spots which will gladly serve you.
author: Jay H.

description: This place is a must go! My boyfriend moved into Nob Hill awhile ago and was dying to come here with me. He wanted to take me forever, and we finally came. The wait wasn't too bad, we sat that the bar. The sushi and sashimi was amazing!!! There is a special sushi roll where they light it on fire in front of you and you wait until it burns out for a good 15 minutes or so. It definitely something special. The rolls are great there and the environment is amazing. I loved the place so much and it was by far one of the best dates !
author: Amy Y.

description: What an experience! Great (quick & friendly) service, cool space, and most of all, amazing food! We even got free shochu shots to wash down a couple of rolls. Small place but worth the wait!!
author: Andy L.

description:
The sushi is high quality, go for the "unusual" house special though, rather than the more traditional fare, I think this is where the place really shines. It might sound strange to have garlic chips on top of your sashimi, but trust me, it's delicious.

I am docking one star because service has gone down slightly lately; I called and was told to come in because there weren't too many people, we rushed over but 10 minutes later the wait for 2 people was already 20 minutes. They take down your number so you can explore the area rather than wait there, which is nice, but after getting the call that our table was ready we still had to wait another 10 minutes to get seat, and generally the wait staff was not very prompt.

Still, the place is busy and sushi takes time to make, so I still recommend this restaurant fully!
author: Luigi A.

description: 5/5 Would come back here just for the himalayan trout. Didn't make a reservation and just stood in line when they opened, and luckily got through the first seating! My favorite for sure was the New Zealand Trout that was served on top of Himalayan rock salt. Also ordered the beastie boy - guess it wasn't my thing as there was too much going on in my mouth that it kind of just overwhelmed me. Don't quite remember the other dishes we ordered, but can't wait to come back!
author: Megan K.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF for sushi! Great prices and high quality. Ya Man roll is one of my favorite rolls along with Boom Box. Rolls are an affordable $9-16 a roll. The restaurant is very small, but if you're in a group of two it's easy to get seated either at the bar or on the floor. If you have a large group I would come an off time or expect to wait 30 min-1 hour. I ate with a friend at 8pm on a Saturday and at least five parties were turned away/didn't want to wait in a 15 min span. 

Overall great atmosphere, quick turn on service when seated and high quality food at a very reasonable price. Only downside is small capacity.
author: Caitlin W.

description:
We had dinner here last night and were lucky to get there right at opening so we were seated right away. There were three of us and sharing four rolls was perfect, our favorite was the flaming sea bass roll but all of the rolls were very good with fresh fish and a good combination of ingredients.  They also have the $5 lychee martini special, which is always a good way to start dinner. :) 

One thing to remember is that they will not seat your party until everyone has arrived, pretty standard for a smaller restaurant but might be good to keep in mind.  And they want you in and out, when we finished our meal they were very antsy for us to wrap up our conversation or take it outside.
author: Gloria N.

description:
The best sushi I have ever had in my entire life! I have tried many different places but never found the same or better sushi! 
They have great dishes such as Himalayan Trout, Flamming Seabass, Yaman, Beastie Boys, Tai Tai. But if you with different options u wouldn't go wrong with ur any choices.
Tips: This place small and very popular so try to come before 6pm on Wed, Thur, and Sundays if you do not want to wait.
author: E U.

description:
Our waitress took down our orders mentally. Checked in w other tables on her way back. Now that's what I call incredible memory!

We got the flaming sea bass, Beastie boy, boom box & a few other rolls. I am not a fan of boom box or Beastie boy- but that's bc I didnt like a raw egg & banana on my sushi (had to try to find out!)

Loved their hello Kitty martini - well balanced. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Minnie S.

description: Best Sushi in SF!!! My gurlfriend was visiting from Maui & so we took a recommendation to go here! First the gal taking names at the door was amazing and super patient with us as we had to push back our table a few times & finally when we were ready she sat us at the sushi bar (perfect) T made us the most delicious Trout we have ever had...we just kept ordering it lol We can't wait to come back!
author: Jessica K.

description: Waitress was great. Some of the sushi technically tasted fine and seemed fresh. However, my problem with it was the portions/false advertising. I ordered the Naked Scallop roll. That leads me to believe scallop is an integral part of the roll. Not so much. In each piece there was maybe the size of a pea worth of scallop. Whole roll couldn't have had more than half a scallop total. The rest was a TON of cucumber and a bit of crab. Then there was the Red Dragon. Shrimp tempura roll topped with tuna. Again, shrimp should be the main attraction, no? I am pretty sure they sliced a shrimp into 4 long pieces. Dipped one of the tiny slices in the stickiest/hardest (think peanut brittle) batter and rolled it up. And of course $8 12oz Sapporo's. Not impressed. Won't be back.
author: Boogs M.

description: Maybe this place is good... who knows... we heard that there was a long wait here so we showed up early and tried to put down our name early when there was no wait. They said we couldn't do that unless we wanted to sit right that second. We said we would wait to put our name down and when we returned an hour later they were "sold out". Unsure what that means, if they are out of food or space but it was a bummer for sure. Good thing there are a few other sushi places around the corner so we ate there and it was great! Okoze was awesome!
author: Andrew C.

description: I'm slightly harsher with the more "trendy," hyped-up spots like Elephant Sushi, but every dish I tried was truly delicious. You can't go wrong with the sashimi or any of the (unique) rolls on the menu. I recommend the Godzilla special, it exceeded my expectations! Cons would be the long wait, loud and crowded space, and higher price point, but what else do you expect with a popular restaurant in SF! Is it the best sushi I've ever tried? No -- but Elephant Sushi is definitely worth checking out!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Best dishes:
-Himalayan trout 
-hamachi truffle
-beastie boys

Great sushi and cheap drinks ($5 hello kitty martinis and $3 sake bombs)

There's usually a wait but it's worth the wait. You can go to one of the wine bars on the block and grab a drink; they'll call you when your table is ready.
author: Vicky H.

description:
One of the things that I absolutely hate is krab with a k. So many "creative" sushi restaurants heavily rely on krab and it's such a turn-off.

I love that Elephant Sushi stays clear of krab and focuses on fresh fish. All of the rolls are fun and innovative. The Flaming Seabass is super cool, the White Out roll is so yummy, and the Rainbow Roll is the best rainbow roll I've ever had.

To often, places that specialize in rolls use poor quality fish but that is not the case at Elephant Sushi. The salmon nigiri sushi was divine as well.

Yes, the wait sucks but that seems like a common problem in SF.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Elephant Sushi is so popular. People start lining up before it even opens (much like any other hyped restaurant in SF). By 6:10, the room was packed..granted it's a pretty small place. 

All I have to say is that you get a lot for what you're paying for. The rice to fish proportion amount is perfect. Huge slices of fish with a bit of rice. But, unfortunately the rice was not vinegared. I was wondering why everything tasted so bland. This was true for both the sushi rolls and the nigiris. At least the fish tasted fresh and the uni was good. 

So if I were to recommend anything, it would be to get their appetizers. I liked the Himalayan Trout and Hamachi Truffle. The sizzling seabass looked like a popular order.

We ordered a lot of food for two people and the bill ended up being $100. Not too bad with all the fish we got but I probably won't come back and wait in line for this.
author: Ingrid C.

description: Omg omg omg. Phenomenal. Best sushi I've ever had. We had the white out as well as the scallop pockets and they were to die for. The sushi is a little bit pricey but it's expected for San Francisco. I also thought that the place was abnormally small. It's so small in fact there's no place to wait inside. The host meets you outside and will not let you inside until you are seated. Which is totally understandable, it's small and very crowded so it completely made sense, just as a heads up!
author: Jennifer G.

description:
This place has phenomenal sushi and very fresh sashimi! Very cozy, intimate setting -good spot for a casual date or food with friends.

Came on a Monday evening and the place was quite full. A lot of tables had ordered the baked halibut (which I will try next time), which comes wrapped in foil and is cooked under a flame at your table.

The fish and pita chips were amazing, as was the stuffed tofu pocket with spicy scallops. The tofu has a slight sweetness to it, which was surprising very good.


We also ordered the Dragon roll which was a favorite of mine.

From NYC but I think I may have found my "sushi spot" in SF!
author: Erica B.

description:
Not impressed. Ordered some O-Toro, hamachi nigiri, himilayan trout sashimi, beastie boy, 8 piece assorted sashimi, and the flaming seabass roll.

The quality of fish was just very grocery store standard. The flaming seabass roll is more for presentation and tasted like a lion king (you're not missing out on much). I'm really shocked this place has such great reviews. We even waited 30 minutes to get seated here whereas Okoze sushi on the corner had no wait. 

They don't have an assortment of special fish, and they don't even have saba (mackerel). They serve escolar fish as walu (aka butterfish). Be careful with escolar consumption! It's not good, just wikipedia it. 

All in all, this place is not worth the hype. Nothing was wrong with the service and I don't have any ill will towards this place. I just don't think it's very good. Tried it once, probably won't come back.
author: Joanna S.

description: I was very depressed about Umami Sushi closing but going to Elephant Sushi gives me hope. After hearing about in on many occasions I finally gave this place a try last night. Got there on a Thursday at 6 pm and didn't have to wait. The restaurant is definitely mostly 2 person tables so if you don't want to wait then I would recommended picking your ONE favorite person and hitting this place up. SUPER fresh sushi - I highly recommend the chips and dip appetizer and the flaming sea bass roll. Also as far as price goes it was I would say it was really reasonable. We got an appetizer and 4 rolls and it was under $100 which I think it great for good sushi.
author: Neilu A.

description:
Try to make a reservation! We got one for my sister's birthday and it was awesome not having to wait in that long line.. but if you can't, then get early to stand in line before they open.

Service: We felt neglected at times and it wasn't the greatest, but it wasn't so bad that it took away from the food experience. 

Ambience: Cramped tables but still a great layout considering the tiny space. 

Food: -Godzilla and albacore tataki: these dishes both had so many textures in one bite! it was a great order to share with everybody. 
-Flaming sea bass: a must. I kept thinking it was a fire hazard but the end result was a phenomenal and delicious dish. 
-Naked scallop: YES! MUST! we got this dish after we finished everything else and had felt a bit hungry.. and I wish we had gotten two orders of this during our meal. all the flavors meld so perfectly together.
-Red dragon roll: mediocre, and we found a piece of saran wrap in ours. 

Great food with great people.
author: Shelley K.

description:
Five stars for the white-out roll alone! Everything else is a bonus. Seriously...best I ever had! 

We stumbled upon this place a little less than a year ago and I haven't stopped thinking about it since! Finally made it back last month and my experience was just as great as I remembered. We told the host we drove from Santa Cruz (we're not crazy, it's that good) and they complimented us with the hamachi truffle. So sweet! 

Try to come before opening or else the wait is crazy, we're talking 2+ hour wait. They also don't accept parties more than 4 people so plan accordingly. Not sure why they won't expand but I'm not complaining!

Thanks for the quality sushi, we'll definitely be back again soon!
author: Lisa H.

description:
So, I literally can't even with Elephant Sushi.  My friends who live in the area swear that this is one of the best places in SF for sushi, so I've known that I needed to at least try here at some point.

My girlfriend and I went here on a Sunday night without a reservation, and found ourselves in a HUGE line that went into the street before their 6pm opening. We thankfully got in and got seats at the sushi bar; usually something I look forward to at sushi places. We decided that we were going to share things, so we went with the Hamachi Truffle, Yummy Pocket, Naked Scallop Roll, and the Godzilla.

My conclusions on just about every single one of the dishes were that nothing here impressed me.  In fact, I couldn't really understand why people wait for hours for this place.  There was WAY too much sriracha on the Godzilla dish, and everything else literally left no impression on me.  So, fine, 3 stars for the food since nothing here was impressive.

Where this goes bad is the service.  I get that you have a huge line of people looking to get in to your restaurant.  But our waitress attempted to clear our dishes while food was still on it (I had to stop her from taking the hamachi off the plate since she was focused on clearing).  While we were were finishing the Godzilla, we noticed that we hadn't been sitting in our seats for more than 30 minutes before coming to the end of dinner.  That's how fast food was coming out.  One dish after the other, and by being at the bar, that means you have to deal with it. Noticing that we had finished fast, we asked our waitress for the banana ice cream.  Not more than 3 minutes later, a small scoop of ice cream showed up as we were trying to finish our fish items.  Yuck. SO yuck. The last thing I want on my palate is tuna and then banana ice cream.  Midway through the weird ice cream/fish experience, our waitress dropped off the check, which was a sign for GTFO.  

We couldn't leave fast enough. I most definitely will not be returning here. Thankfully, this place wasn't expensive, otherwise I probably would have said something to the manager that night.  If you appreciate good sushi, you'll steer clear of a place that has gained popularity because of their cheap sake bombs. No thanks.
author: Lisa I.

description:
My lovely fiancé and I were out to celebrate on the eve of our departure to wed and decided to drop some coin on some good sushi. This was our second visit to Elephant sushi but it would also be our last. 

The first issue was the hostess- wifey stopped in to check the wait and was told 30-45 mins, the hostess took her cell phone number and said she'd call when they were dropping the check. Guess who's phone NEVER rang? After an hour at a wine bar across the street I went to inquire and was told she called and no one answered. We were starving at this point and watching her phone quite hawkishly so we're certain it didn't ring. 

Next, we're sat and delivered our bottle of ginjo sake. I stress delivered, not served, as our server placed it on the table and asked if we were ready to order- didn't even open the bottle let alone pour a glass. When I asked a question about a sushi roll our server just stared at me blankly as her English was not passable. Fail. Fine we'll just figure it out. 

One of the rolls we ordered, the Flaming Seabass, was again delivered not served. They light the roll on fire at our table and we weren't warned that the bowl is extremely hot- yeah we figured it out without major incident but it seems like quite the liability to not at least warn us not to touch the bowl. As we watch this tinfoil burn we start to wonder- how long do we wait? Our server Moogii returned as she noticed us trying to unwrap the flaming roll and we asked her how long it's to stay lit, to which she replied 2-3 minutes. Weird. It'd been burning for at least 5-6! She leaves with it still on fire so we blow it out and try to get into it. Moogii eventually came to help us sort it out but as you can imagine, the roll was overcooked- falling all apart and the hoisin sauce is burnt. 

All in all, the food was good but all aspects of the service were dreadful. Tip reflected and my wife's in the industry so she hates under tipping, but our server earned it. We let her know about it via guest comment card too. How else they gonna learn? That and Yelp.
author: c d.

description: Best sushis experience ever! This wonderful familial restaurant is owned by wonderful people, you can trust them, they will cook wonders for your taste! Try Himalayan Trout and Chips N Dip for example ;)...sophisticated and amazing, I love this restaurant sooooo much, you can't miss this place!!! :D
author: Camille L.

description:
Elephant Sushi is my favorite sushi restaurant in Nob Hill.  

Don't let their janky website fool you. Judging from the decor and ambiance, the restaurant feels rather hip and trendy.  It's small, so you might want to make a reservation or go right when they open for dinner to avoid waiting.

I highly recommend getting:

1. The White Out Roll - Yellowtail & avocado roll topped with seared butter fish & garlic ponzu sauce. It literally melts in your mouth. You'll wonder why other foods can't be like this.  They just can't

2. Scallop Nigiri - Super fresh & slightly sweet. This also just melts in your mouth.  Other nigiri that I've tried here have also been great, but the scallop is the most memorable. I normally get two orders!

3. Truffle Hamachi - Come on. Hamachi in truffle oil, topped with fried garlic? Amazing.

4. Kobe Dragon Roll - Seared Kobe beef, on a roll. What's not to like?

The Godzilla Roll receives an honorable mention. It's shrimp tempura wrapped in tuna, sitting in some spicy sauce (siracha? I can't remember).  The beastie boys are worth trying, but I'm not sure if I would get them again.  A lot of flavors, some great, some not so great. Loved the uni, quail egg & shiso leaf, but there was one other thing in there that was just meh.

Anyway, if you're in Nob Hill, and looking for a moderately priced sushi dinner, this might be the spot for you. And by moderately priced, I mean about $100 for two people.  The service has always been fantastic, and they don't judge you if your boyfriend orders a Hello Kitty martini.

For those of you wondering...Yes, their menu is suspiciously similar to Saru in Noe Valley.
author: Grace C.

description:
This was my absolute favorite sushi restaurant until a recent unpleasant experience. My parents were visiting San Francisco and we wanted them to experience great sushi, so we decided to go to Elephant Sushi. The restaurant has a strict policy of not taking parties more than 4 people, which we were aware of. We had a group of 6 people and we're hoping that we could at least sit near each other or at the bar. When we arrived to the restaurant we asked the hostess if we could sit at one table of four and have two others sit at the table right next to it. Both tables were available and they refused to accommodate our request. We sat at the table of four and the hostess sat my parents across the restaurant. The table for two right next to us was empty the ENTIRE time we were at the restaurant. The hostess could not provide a valid reason as to why my parents could not sit at the empty table. We asked to speak to a manger multiple times and she refused to come out. Before we left, the waitress handled us a post it with an email address for us to contact the manager with our issue. It was extremely disappointing to see the lack of customer service and ability to grant a simple request. It was disgusting how spiteful the situation was handled considering there was an empty table right next to ours. It was as if they were trying to be nasty.   
This was my parents last night in town and our evening was completely ruined. I will never come back to this establishment and I will tell others about our horrible experience of this poorly managed restaurant.
author: Vivian D.

description:
Cute little sushi spot. Sushi was good, similar to most sf sushi joints. 

One specialty here is their flaming sushi roll. Must try if you do visit.
author: Claire W.

description: The best Sashimi and Sushi I've ever had!  My husband and I loves the Himalayan trout when you take a bite it just melts in your mouth, we also ordered the Albacore that also lays on the bed of Himalayan salt and also every time we come here I always get the Flaming sea bass yummm.... Staff are great and sushi chef's are great!
author: Diane M.

description:
A fun place for a date or a celebration. Unfortunately it's quite small so groups larger than 4 are unlikely to be seated until the communal table frees up.

The owner is super sweet and helpful. Which helps when the wait is over 45 mins. She seems to play the host most of the night. 

I came here once with my husband and enjoyed a couple of appetizers and rolls. I don't recall what we ordered exactly but the sashimi salad was over dressed that night.

We had a group of 5 tonight. We were seated within 45 mins. We ordered the hamachi bites, hamachi truffle oil, otoro nigiri, ya man, spicy hamachi, beastie boys, flaming seabass, boom box, and another with salmon (cannot remember the names). Overall the quality of food is great and portions are reasonable but expect to be ordering more than usual.

There menu appears to have expanded since I last came with my husband. Looking forward to returning.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
great sushi! very fresh, very masterful. 
we were told at first that there was an hour wait, but the wait list doesn't apply to the bar, which is totally the place to sit. from there you can watch the masters do their work. 
loved the red and yellow roll, the ya man, and the alaska. i'm a sucker for salmon +avocado, and it hunk simple rolls like that are a way to showcase freshness. the flaming seabass is impressive, and definitely a spectacle. but i'm still not sure as to how i feel about hot sushi. it was tasty, but not my favorite. 
overall, great experience.
author: Rita K.

description: Very yummy Thai near us in encino. My girls love the shrimp Salong. We also love the spicy fried rice, Panang curry and drunken noodles. Try it out!
author: Kris G.

description:
Awesome place to have a group dinner. We got the big (cool looking) table in the back. Even though the sushi is more California-fusion as opposed to traditional style, it was an amazing meal!

+ house pickled ginger
+ flaming sea bass roll was pretty bad ass
+ hamachi truffle is a must have
+ also is the naked scallop roll
+ 2 dollar sake bombs, say wha?
+ phenomenal service
author: Sherry L.

description:
Trendy sushi place for those who are fans of overly-dressed sushi rolls. The sushi quality itself is quite good compared to other places in the city, but this is not a traditional sushi bar where you should expect to order nigiri or sashimi. In my opinion, their famous sea bass roll did not live up to the hype. Rather it was just too much, in terms of sauce a mixture of textures. Unlike some other sushi restaurants though, I will say their fish ratio is pretty solid - they don't skimp on flavors or fish proportion. 

It's a pretty small place, so try to make a reservation or you may end up waiting for an hour plus. Great place for a date or to catch up with girlfriends, but definitely expect to spend a good amount.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Yes.  This is as good as they say.

Yes.  You need to get there at 5:40 pm if you want a table when they open at 6.

Yes.  You should most definitely order as much as you can, because the food is fresh, lovingly crafted, and of very high quality.

Yes.  If you order "chicken teriyaki" or "California rolls" here, I will un-friend you.
author: Tori S.

description:
Elephant sushi! Best sushi I've ever had. We live a couple blocks away and eat here at least twice a month. 

The fish is always fresh, the flavors are so unique, and the whole experience is always consistent.

The only downsides are they don't take groups larger than 4 and there is always a wait. I wish they took reservations.
author: H K.

description:
This sushi is the best of the best.  I was here with some friends and they REALLY hyped the place up before I even got there... I had VERY high expectations.  I have to say that Elephant Sushi definitely far exceeded my expectations.  The restaurant is located on small corner in Russian Hill.  There are two levels with the top level being the restaurant and the bottom level being the restroom.  The restaurant, itself, isn't too big so make sure you call ahead to put your name down for a table.  

The staff is extremely friendly and they make FANTASTIC recommendations.  Our server was able to help our small group of 5 pick several dishes that we could share.  We had several rolls but my favorite had to be the flaming roll that our server recommended.  I believe it was with trout... The fish was really delicious and I loved the flame made for a really cool show.  I also love that the SAKE BOMBS are really well-priced... I think $2 per bomb? An excellent way to make an nice night extremely FUN! 

Pros:
-Great Staff
-Amazing selection of fish
-BOMB sake

Cons:
-Crowded

Tips:
-Call ahead to get your name on the list for a table
author: Michelle H.

description: The food here is definitely quite good. On the other hand, it is definitely on the noisy/crowded end of things, and the service is mediocre. I would come back, but probably not at peak time.
author: Gianna M.

description:
This is a great place for rolls. They do an excellent job of introducing new and interesting flavors/combinations to the dishes they serve. If you're looking for good old traditional amazing nigiri, keep looking - this ain't that kinda place.

We came in as a party of 2 on a Wed night about 20 mins before they opened. We were the first in line. They take reservations but the place didn't seem to fill up until maybe half an hour or so after they opened, so I don't think they are necessarily needed unless you have a bigger party or want to come at the dinner rush hour. Come early if you want to sit at the bar though.

Being too poor for my usual $80-120 per person splurging that I do when I want quality sushi, I found this place on yelp to see if it would fit my needs for decent sushi at a reasonable price. It definitely exceeded my expectations.

Quality of fish: above average by SF sushi restaurant comparison, but nowhere near the best. They get extra points here for the large and generous portions of fish that they cut
Quality of chefs: above average, giving extra points for creativity and flavor
Quality of rice: bad... Too hard. It definitely stood out when I ordered nigiri
Nigiri: they don't do it right. The rice falls off easily and there is no wasabi under the fish
Prices: pretty fair

Summary: Don't come here for nigiri or expecting the best sushi in SF. Come here for rolls and you won't be disappointed.

Pro tip: $2 sake bombs
author: Joanne Y.

description: My husband and I were visiting SF from out of town and walked into this place. We sat down and ordered a beer and a martini. I have the habit of looking on Yelp before ordering and this time was not the exception. When I looked on Yelp I noticed an Alert that said Poor Food Safety Quality (have never seen that with any of the restaurants), it was then that we decided we weren't eating. When the waitress came to ask what we wanted to order from the food menu we said we were okay and she left. She came back 5 minutes later and told us that we had to leave because this place was designed for dining and not drinking. I have never experienced this before, last time I checked restaurants make most of their money from alcoholic drinks. We felt offended since we were consuming and were being kicked out of this place. Feeling frustrated I told her our initial plan was to order food but due to the alert on Yelp we did not. She stated that they failed the food safety rating because of a machine that was not working that day. I have never experienced such bad service!! I will definitely never visit this place when in SF!
author: Siboney L.

description: To begin with, service was terrible. The waitress forgot everything we ordered and then, one of our chairs broke to pieces, throwing a patron to the floor. When we asked for a discount for the broken chair, their manager insisted that we did not deserve a discount by flailing his arms in front of our whole table. When he saw that we witnessed his motions, he smiled and walked away. Outside of the restaurant, the manager was smoking a cigarette and approached us, accusing us of breaking their chair. When we said we would not be returning our business, the manager gave us the middle finger as we left. We have never experienced the level of disrespect we received from Elephant Sushi.
author: Alli B.

description:
Elephant sushi is very, very good. Fresh fish, creative rolls and light on the rice. It's one of the few places that I always bring out-of-towners to that has gotten 100% positive feedback. Unlike most hyped SF restaurants, the long wait won't lead to disappointment here. You'll be full and happy and it's reasonably priced as well.

My only complaint is that it's almost too fish focused. Every roll and even every appetizer has fish. I need something fried or at least some miso soup for variety.
author: Emily H.

description:
This place is pretty small for an "elephant" yet so popular, resulting in a horrendous wait. We were a group of 4 and waited about 1 hour on a Thursday night because there was only one table that could fit four people. When we arrived, the people had been almost finished, but unfortunately took their sweet time chatting and hanging out...leaving us drooling and staring from outside.  There's definitely more turnaround with a party of 2. 

They will take your name and call you when your table is ready, so feel free to go grab some wine or ice cream nearby on Hyde Street while you wait.

The prices were pretty on point with the quality of the fish. We ordered the following dishes:

Appetizers:
Chips n dip ($10 / 4 pieces) - 5 STARS!
Hamachi Truffle ($15 / 6 pieces) - 3 STARS...I expected more 
Walu carpaccio ($15 / 6 pieces) - 3 STARS
Fatty tuna - blue fin tuna appetizer ($22 / 6 pieces)- 5 STARS

Rolls:
Godzilla roll ($13 / 6 pieces) - 3 STARS
White out roll ($15 / 8 pieces) - 5 STARS. My favorite roll of the night
Spicy hamachi roll ($9 / 6 pieces) - 4 STARS
Ya man roll ($12 / 8 pieces) - 5 STARS

They also have $5 hello kitty martinis and $2 sake bombs all the time. Their "happy hour" is all the time, but only consists of these two drinks. 

The quality of the fish is excellent, and the menu is overall delicious and inventive. This isn't your ordinary sushi joint. I definitely recommend it! Just expect to wait a bit.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is a great spot for reasonably priced, fresh sushi and delicious drinks. From the start, the waiter was friendly and knowledgeable, giving us detailed recommendations for food and complimenting drinks. He was especially knowledgeable regarding the different textures and tastes of the sashimi, which was extremely helpful for a novice sashimi-phile like myself. My date and I ended up ordering the albacore tataki, the white out roll, the boombox roll (?), and some hot sake. The albacore tataki was smokey, rich, and absolutely amazing. The white out roll was buttery, smooth, and just plain delicious. The boombox roll was "meh" for me. I wasn't a fan of the banana in the sushi since I don't have much of a sweet tooth, especially for sushi... But whatever... My date ordered it. 

All things considered, the meal was absolutely worth the 1 hour wait and 60$ (pre-tip) price tag. I will absolutely be back here when I visit SF.

Note: My date and I were crazy full after our meal, but we had stopped by Stones Throw down the block for a snack and a drink during our hour wait. (There's tons of awesome bars in the vicinity, so don't fret the wait if you're not in a hurry! It makes for a great date night!)
author: Alex T.

description:
I haven't found better sushi in SF. Four sushi chefs in this small place makes for an exciting show, if you like to sit at the sushi bar. Great energy also comes from busy but efficient servers. 

There are lots of choices, imaginative yet not crazy. You will not find fresher fish anywhere else. 

The place opens at 6, and a line forms outside beforehand. It's best to make a reservation. If they can get away with naming it Elephant Sushi, it has to be good!
author: Will L.

description: Had a great meal. Showed up just at opening with open seating but within 10 minutes the place was full! Ordered albacore , eel ( not my favorite) . And flaming sea  was aMazing!  .Service  was on point and meal was enjoyable.
author: Kathy T.

description: Worst service I have ever experienced. They took over 2 hours to give me a table when they only told me 1 and they were very disrespectful. Will never be returning or referring anyone here.
author: Jaime L.

description:
I was really excited to try this place tonight.  The food was not bad but the service sucked.  We had a 45 min. Our server did not come by to refill our water at all during the entire meal.    

When my friend dropped her chopsticks, we couldn't get anyone's attention.  So, she went up to a server at the bar who was prepping napkins and asked for a new pair.  The woman's response was, "ask your server."  

I felt rushed because they brought us the check the moment we finished our last piece of sushi.  At the end of our meal, the chopstick-refusing server came over and asked if we needed anything else.  I asked for some more water and she was said, "sure but people are waiting for this table so..."  I turned to look around and saw there was an empty table behind us and nobody waiting outside. 

I'm definitely not recommending this place to anyone - there are plenty of other sushi places where you don't have as long of a wait time and won't get rushed out.
author: Shir K.

description: Worst service I've ever seen. I watched a guy fall through a broken chair and not a single person from the restaurant walked over or even acknowledge that it happened. That was just the beginning for us.  We then received terrible service where the waitress brought the incorrect orders several times and was completely careless when we attempted to correct the mistakes, telling us that we "asked for the wrong thing". We ended the night watching two of the managers getting into a confrontation with a patron out front acting belligerent and completely unprofessional.  I now know terrible service from a first hand experience, save your money and patron a restaurant which values their customers.
author: Rob D.

description: Great place with exciting dishes and fun, crowded, bar-like atmosphere.  Try the Beastie Roll and monk fish liver!
author: M S.

description:
For an elitist who prefers nigiri only, I must say the design of the rolls at Elephant Sushi definitely impressed me.  The rolls were very innovative, and the fish used was very fresh.  None of that spicy mayo overload crap, or imitation crab meat.  If omakase is your thing, i probably wouldn't come out of your way to try this.  If rolls are you thing, this place is stellar.

PROTIP:  The wait is horrible and there is no way around it due to their limited number of tables.
author: David C.

description:
Three years ago when the location was still Sushi Groove, my girlfriend and I came here for supper. I remembered telling her, "this place looked familiar." Then it dawned on me that this was the restaurant I practically camped out at in the late 90s, it was one of those date restaurants and I was in my early to mid 20s, which made this place ideal because it was convenient and suitably date-worthy.

While the name and presumably, ownership, has changed, and there were approx. 17/18 years of time in between my old and new memories, this place remained to be a a date -worthy neighborhood restaurant. It consistently offers a quality sushi bar with nice array of drinks to compliment the food. In 1998, lichee sake cocktails was in, it would appear that it had since made a nice come back. The renovated model was clearly updated, the clientele remained youngish, and the service remained professional. I continue to enjoy the bar seating,  which, as any sushi aficionado will tell you, is the only place to sit when enjoying sushi. I like this born again version more, perhaps because the memories created since the change-over seemed more relevant. The ginger in a jar and help yourself model works for me. The quality of sushi seemed to have improved, in my opinion. I would stay with the nigiri because good sushi needs no sauce. The fusion side of the offering in this restaurant is enticing enough, rolls are filled with ample fish and delightful sauces. The fanciful ones with flame always seemed to please the patrons. 

I never had to order when coming here. The person I'm usually with has been a long term patron like me since the late 90s as well, and has practically the same exact taste as I when it comes to sushi. He does the ordering, I do the eating. Pretty simple and hassle free. A good test for a decent sushi restaurant is the freshness of uni, and I noticed he tends to always order that wherever we go out for sushi, which we had been doing for as long as we have known each other. This to me is the place that had the very best uni, and they tell you up front that it's a one bite nigiri. Don't attempt to be lady like when consume beastie boys and / or uni nigiri, or you'd look anything but a lady after. 

We never had to wait and there is always a good chance that we could be in and out in an hour, as the service is very prompt, so that we could get on with the rest of our evening without feeling that we had spent the entire evening waiting to get served. 

And of course this being a place I frequented in my 20s, does not hurt either.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Elephant Sushi is THE BEST sushi I have ever had. There are many great sushi restaurants in San Francisco, but very few are memorable and worthy of repeat visits. 

We came here last Friday and despite parking being a nightmare and the one hour wait outside, in the cold...I WOULD DO IT ALL AGAIN. By the time we were seated at the bar, I was starving. Fortunately, one of the sushi chefs handed us a complementary plate of seared butter fish, which was absolute perfection (and a very sweet gesture!). I immediately became very excited because I knew if that one little piece of fish was THAT good, then the food to come was going to be amazing. And it was. 

THE FOOD:
- Yummy Pocket (House Special): Sweet tofu skins stuffed with spicy bay scallops, scallions, and sushi rice. These were really fun to eat and were indeed yummy pockets bursting with flavor! 

- White Out Roll: Hamachi, seared butterfish, and avocado...this roll was anything but monotone. Great texture, flavor, and presentation. Probably my favorite roll. 

- Ya Man Roll: Salmon with a spicy pesto; I love salmon and this one was a winner! 

- Flaming Sea Bass Roll: An absolute must-get! Very similar to a baked lion king roll, the Flaming Sea Bass comes out on a flaming bowl, wrapped in foil, and is cooked right in front of you. Creamy, decadent, and a little bit sweet. If there's a ton of rice stuck to your foil at the end, ask your server for a spoon to scrape the tasty burnt bits!

- Monkfish Liver (Nigiri): The liver was mild in flavor and had the texture of pate. Very interesting, although probably my least favorite compared to the other rolls. 

We were so pleased with our meal that we wanted to order more even though we were full. Unfortunately, when we tried to order some uni (sea urchin) they were sold out for the night.  If you're a fan of it, get here early! 

The service was absolutely wonderful, from the hostess (who was gracefully dealing with the hoards of people trying to get tables) to the servers to the sushi chefs. A special shoutout to Miken for being our awesome server for the night! He was friendly, funny, super chill, and made sure we were well taken care of. 

On average, the rolls are between $10-15, while some of the house specials and sashimi get into the $20 range, but the quality of the fish is so unquestionably fresh and delicious that the prices are more than worth it. They don't take same-day reservations after 6pm, so do call ahead of time! If you're waiting though, they take your number and will call you when you're on deck, so feel free to grab a drink at the wine bar up the street...or take a peek at Swenson's Ice Cream flavors for your after-dinner dessert! The restaurant is pretty small inside - about 8 tables,  6 bar seats, and one large table for groups. I was initially a bit disappointed we got bar seats, but they're actually some of the best seats in the house since you have a front row view of the rolls being made and an interactive experience with the sushi chefs. I cannot wait to go back! Highly recommend and one of my new favorites!
author: Deanna Y.

description: Each piece of sashimi is fresh, tender, mouthwateringly delicious. The Ya Man Roll has a perfect kick of spice added to it, definitely will get again. Loved the seabass and walu in the Omakase special.
author: J L.

description:
We waited about 1-1.5 hours, good thing there were places to hang at in the mean time. Wine bar near by, along with sport bars.

Food: exceptional. Every single thing we had was good, the real problem was figuring out what we liked the most.  All the fish was fresh, flaming sea bass had so much flavor ( roll tends to fall apart from being cooked), but best of all was that each bite had some type of unique flavor. Cannot wait to come back. 

Cons: none? Only thing I would change is the wait time, but that for me doesn't factor into the restaurants overall quality.
author: Joseph Rebelo R.

description: Would be good if the hostess knew basic math and would fit people in who were waiting an hour and a half vs. 30 minutes. I've eaten here before. Not worth the hassle.
author: Catie F.

description:
This place is delicious...! White out roll is so yummy. 

Solongo the hostess in front was so sweet and nice. Even tho she had to say no to a ton of people, she was so sweet about it. Such great service! Will come back again for her and the food.
author: Thach N.

description:
I was quite disappointed with my dinner here on a Friday night. I got there early expecting it to be busy and waiting for a table which was fine. But when I mentioned I was a group of 5 right away we were shut down. They said they only will take even numbers or a group of 8 at a back table. My group had accommodated by splitting 2 and 3 and hoping we would at least maybe sit close to each other. 
When we got back an hour later they completely split us up across the restaurant. 3 at the bar and 2 by the window. We saw a table opening up near the bar to see if we could at least sit close by but they said no! 
We eventually sat down after trying to ask for them to accommodate something but still nothing was done to make us somewhat happy.  Eventually we ordered in our separate seats and then seats opened beside us at the bar. We asked if our friends could be moved and again they said no! Once your sitting and ordered you can't be moved. 
We noticed a table to the left of the restaurant that clearly sits a bigger group. They had two groups of 3 sitting there which were not together... Clearly a communal table. We were quite disappointed that they did not offer that option for us 5! We easily would have shared with other people so we could of sat together. 
A friend in our group was gluten free and had been there before where there was no problem... Well they made it a problem for her that day saying they could not change certain meals for her (which was not the case with her visit before). 
The kicker was when we had to pay our bill... they would not let us split the bill 3 ways with credit cards. We had to do 2 only. Which I get it can be annoying to split multiple ways on a bill... But just for 3 seemed a little ridiculous. 
Well to say the least I'm very disappointed!! The food there is incredible but due to the service my friends and I received I doubt we'll be going back any time soon. There are many other sushi restaurants that will make their customers happy.
author: Ela B.

description:
Trekking to Russian Hill to eat at Elephant Sushi is worth it. !!!
We got seated right away and the service was super friendly and quick. Also, I was never thirsty because our waitress was so prompt about refilling my water cup throughout the night. 
The boyfriend and I shared three rolls and they were all so delicious! The fish were fresh and each roll was unique and delightfully presentable. I highly recommend the Ya Man roll if you are a fan of salmon, the White Out if you love hamachi, and the Flaming Sea Bass if you want a hot sushi roll. They were all so good! The Flaming Sea Bass comes out about 7 minutes before you can actually eat it so you can see it being cooked right in front of you. Cooked from flames ignited by alcohol- how exciting.
Elephant Sushi also has their own pickled ginger that comes out in its own mason jar- I'm pretty sure I ate a whole ginger by myself. 
I would definitely come here again and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a sushi place in the city. Go, go, go!
author: Grace L.

description:
This place has GOT to be one of my favorite sushi places in SF! The only problem is that its TOO FAR FROM ME! lol...but that is clearly a me problem..and I need to move. Pronto.

Came here for dinner on a random weeknight and lo' and behold..A WAIT. Ugh. I wouldn't have minded all that much if it weren't freezing outside..but oh well. It was pretty worth it when we got inside.

The THREE MOST YUMILICIOUS Highlights that are MUST-HAVES:

1, Flaming sea bass roll - Yes, its worth the hype. Yes, they light it on fire. and yes, people will oogle your table with envy when it comes out..and they haven't ordered it!

2. Hamachi truffle - I LOVE TRUFFLE. And Hamachi. So clearly, this was a winner for me. Super refreshing and love how fresh it tasted...mmm....drool.

3. Beastie boys  - This is what you came for! SO OBVIOUSLY you would order it!! Seriously though..if you like uni, you will not regret it.

Minus ONE...only because we waited effing forever. (Dear Owner, can you please make this place bigger or open one in SoMA?!?!...iwillloveyouforeverthankyousomuch!)

The end.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I hate to be the one to mention the elephant in the room, but Elephant Sushi is the worst Sushi I have ever had in my entire life.  They have hack Sushi Chefs who are clueless on preparing and presenting sushi.  The flaming sea bass was totally gross, and a disgusting mess when the foil was unwrapped. 

It is a new one on me to see all the fish at the sushi bar wrapped up in brown paper towels, such a lovely presentation and so very appetizing.

They do not have a full bar, and the place is super small with only a few tables.
author: Bill K.

description:
The salmon is amazing every time I have been here. It is worth coming back simply to have more salmon sushi.

I was initially pulled into trying this place because the Beastie Boys looked so interesting. Like many of the other review have said, it ended up being my least favorite thing. It just had too many rich flavors and textures going on for one bite. The poke bowl was fairly good. Most of the rolls have too much going on for my taste, but are well presented. I usually stick with the straight sushi.

The interior is dark and intimate, great place to take a date. Wait time was between 30-60 minutes, on weekends and week days. Luckily there are several great wine bars on the block to pass the time until they call you for your seating.

Only complaint I've had is with the service. The first time I went here we ordered drinks, waited 15 minutes without them showing up, asked again, waited another 15 minutes, and then asked a third time before finally procuring them. By this point we had already finish 75% of our dinner without the drinks.
author: Michael S.

description: Expensive, but worth it if you don't order too much food. The best roll is the one on fire, definitely a must get. The hamachi crudo is also delicious.
author: Diana A.

description:
Pretty damn impressive.  I see why this place usually has a line longer than *****'s ****.  Speaking of which, we somehow got lucky and were seated almost immediately, as all the other waiting parties had either wandered out of the hostess's earshot or were a non-couple number of people.  

We ordered six things; five were huge winners.  Nice record, Elephant sushi!
- Walu (super white tuna) Carpaccio.  Winner!
- Himalayan Trout nigiri.  This is a highly "salmon-like" fish, served with excellent seasoning.  Do it.
- Toro nigiri.  Huge pieces!  Order it while the world's oceans still have it.  A good value at $12 / pair.
- "Basil Salmon," which also included olive oil and was delicious.  
- "White Out Roll" which was as good as the sum of its parts: Avocado, Walu, and Hamachi.  Why didn't I invent this myself?

We also had the "flaming seabass" which was good not great, plus some tasty sweet cold sake and a large Kirin.

Not cheap, but highly recommended anyway.
author: Aaron M.

description: Yes I loved this place...cheap drinks $2 sake bomb quality sushi, banana, salmon, scallion yum. Himalayan trout on brick of salt melted in my mouth...busy atmosphere loud music great for small group. Hotly recommend a reservation!
author: Ribec F.

description:
Mmm mm - so good!!

This place is SMALL... but we were able to be seated relatively quickly at 7:30 on a Tuesday. The place got packed soon after, so i think it just depends!

Notables:

1. Beastie boys - 5 stars - creamy uni, quail egg, and the perfect amount of ankimo. what more can you ask for?
2. Himalayan trout - 5 stars - perfect quality trout (salmon-ish) on a unique salt stone. Not a huge fan of the peppers, but still a great dish

Okay:
1. The scallops in tofu pocket - this one was just okay only. One of the cheaper items on the menu, and probably for a reason!!
2. Sea bass roll - I wish i had gotten a less heavy roll!!

The waiters are all extremely friendly and the hostess was so sweet and helpful! Great with dealing with large crowds of hungry people, which to me is always impress. (I'm one of the crankiest of hungry people.)

Must try!!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I rest my case with this place!  My case being, I only like trying Sushi when I'm close to the ocean and the fish is fresh!

This was not only the best sushi I have ever had but was also one of the best "seafood" type dinners I have ever had.  This is a great little place, tucked in a good neighborhood not far from all the touristy stuff around.  We didn't have reservations and the wait wasn't to bad, especially considering there was a nice little wine bar a few doors down.  

The service was top notch!  From the attitude, recommendations and the flaming plate of Sea bass we ordered, which our waitress timed perfect!  That's right, try the flaming sea bass, wrapped in foil and seated over a plate of flaming Saki this was the best dish of the night!  The Sea bass was wrapped around a tasty filling and cooked to perfection.  Every item we ordered, and there were a lot of them, was fresh, creative and worth the visit alone!

I wanted to come back here before we left, it was that good.  I will return to this beautiful city by the bay again soon and this will have to be a must stop along the way!

KT
author: kyle t.

description:
Delicious, fresh sushi in a small environment. Service is always quick and friendly with no unnecessary frills. This has set the bar for my sushi experiences in the city. However the downside is that it always feels like an ordeal to grab dinner here because of the no-reservation policy mixed with such a small space. Also they recently raised their prices and got rid of their Lagunitas IPA. Still worth the 5 stars! 

If you want a delicious sushi dinner with the price tag to match and don't mind either waiting for what can sometimes be an hour and a half or getting there right upon opening, then this is the best place in the area.
author: Bry F.

description:
ATTENTION SUSHI LOVERS:  If you have not eaten here yet your bucket list has just increased by one!

Get over here, NOW!!!!

There is so much to rave about this place I hardly know where to begin.  The ambiance is awesome, the service is AWESOME, the food is A-W-E-S-O-M-E, and three of us left satiated with sushi and sashimi for under $100 before tip!  If I lived closer I'd be here on a weekly basis.  The only drawback was the lack of parking (welcome to San Francisco!) but the wonderful culinary experience made even SF's traffic and notoriously inadequate parking fade from memory.  The dining area is tiny, maybe a dozen tables and maybe eight seats at the bar, so make sure you make a reservation!

We ordered some of both the exotic and the more familiar sushi rolls and while the exotic dishes were the most memorable all of the sushi and sashimi tasted fresh and delicious and were beautifully prepared.  Each serving came with between six and eight pieces.  So based on our dinner tab the pricing worked out to roughly $2 per piece of sushi or sashimi. 

In our opinion the best dish of the night was the Himalayan Trout - this consisted of New Zealand trout served sashimi style on a block of pink Himalayan salt.  This novel presentation on a salt block imparted just enough seasoning to the sashimi so that soya sauce was totally unnecessary.  We ordered this twice.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/elephant-sushi-san-francisco?userid=weI3gUj0DiKXkp8seBYKfw#pm-nWFG6Wt5AHULHGLDibQ

The flaming seabass (sushi wrapped up in foil and cooked at your table over an alcohol flame) is another Must Try here.  This was a totally unique idea, who ever thought of cooked sushi!  It was fantastic: fresh fish and steamed rice in a sushi roll!

We also tried the Boom Box which was sushi topped with ripe banana, another delicious and innovative creation - but only if you like bananas.    

FYI, I usually bath my sushi in soya sauce and wasabi, but here at Elephant Sushi I barely used the stuff because each dish was bursting with flavor already!

Despite a full house our orders came out fast (almost too quick!) and the hostess and servers were super friendly.  We all left well fed and very happy.  Thank you Elephant Sushi for one of our best dining experiences EVER!
author: Ethan Z.

description:
I don't understand why people like this place. I'm kicking myself for trying Elephant Sushi again.  

The sushi was mushy and stringy- we couldn't finish either order: "Chips n Dip" & Ya Men.  The waitress either didn't notice OR (more likely) didn't care that we obviously we're unhappy with our meal, having left the majority of each dish on the plate.

Service was attentive UNTIL the food was dropped off.

Won't be going back.
author: R D.

description: One of my most favorite sushi spots. Get the Himalayan Sea Trout, Flaming Sea Bass and don't forget the Beastie Boy nigiri. Great owners and they make their own soy sauce and ginger. I love this place
author: SF Y.

description:
WORST customer service I have ever experienced at any restaurant in my life. I dined here on a Friday night with 3 other friends. We put our name in at 6pm, and were asked to wait an hour. No big deal, I expected the wait. Returned as 7PM, was asked to wait another 20 minutes for a table that was finishing. Fine- still didn't bother me- i know this place has a long wait for good sushi. FINALLY we sit down around 7:30. We ordered our food which came out 10-15 minutes later. The sushi was very tasty, but hardly filling, We ordered 4 beers, 5 sushi rolls, two large bottles of Saki. About 25 minutes had passed and we had inhaled our sushi. Keep in mind the time line here, we had only been sitting for about 40 minutes at the table at this point. Also keep in mind we were at a SHARED table- a different group of three other people were at our same table. Our 40 minutes inside the restaurant from sitting to being done with our sushi goes by... we all still have half a beer left. 

Our check comes, I put down my card right away, and the check comes back in less than a minute. Great, but we are in no hurry- we paid $200 for a meal and all still had half a beer left. 5 minutes goes by since we have paid the check and WE ARE ASKED BY OUR SERVER TO GET UP AND LEAVE THE RESTAURANT!! Are you kidding me? NEVER in my life have I been asked to leave a restaurant within 40 minutes, when I still have a drink left, after paying a $200 meal. I get it- maybe if we ordered one roll of sushi and had been there for an hour and a half- ask us to leave because the table needs to be freed up. But FORTY minutes for a table of four and every single one of us has a drink left!! We blew the waitress off assuming she was out of her damn mind for asking us to leave, and continued our conversation and drinks. Is it a crime to casually finish your drink at the end of dinner? 

Three more minutes go by, we are asked A SECOND TIME TO GET UP AND LEAVE!!! THEY LINED UP 5 GIRLS NEXT TO US TO TAKE OUR TABLE!! We were all appalled at this kind of customer service. NOT EVEN AN HOUR HAD GONE BY that they had asked us TWICE to leave the restaurant because we had paid the bill and someone else needed to take our table. DAMN at least give us an hour to sit down!! 

I have absolutely never in my life experienced worse customer service than this. We non-politely let them know that this was a completely unacceptable way to treat paying customers, and let the girls standing next to us know that we had been kicked out of the restaurant so that they could take our table when we hadn't even been sitting for an hour. OH and they group next to us was there before us and still eating- but they were not asked to leave because they ordered one roll of sushi at a time as opposed to all at once, and hadn't paid their bill yet. 

Moral of the story- if you insist on eating here, be strategic. DON'T PAY YOUR BILL RIGHT AWAY or you will get kicked out, DON'T dine here with more than 4 people ever, they will be extremely rude to you and you probably won't fit. And don't expect to wait less than an hour to sit down. 

I truly hope that you train your servers to NEVER treat a paying customer this way unless they have disrespected you by ordered one roll of sushi and sitting down for 2 hours. But we ordered a $200 meal and had not even been sitting for an hour. This is totally unheard of and no way to treat your customers. I'm extremely disappointed. I live up the street and would have spent a lot of money eating here. But after this experience I certainly will not be coming back. I will give my money to the sushi restaurant across the street.
author: Julie F.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend Friday. WARNING: parking can be hell in this area! If you're afraid of driving on hills... you may want to take the bus or you can drive a bit further to avoid the hills but walk a bit. Anyway, onto the dining experience.

The chips n dip was actually my favorite item of the meal. When we were ordering, I didn't think too much of it. After I ate it though, it was very flavorful and I liked whatever the "chip" was, which didn't get soggy and stayed crunchy the entire time.
