Kind of reminded me of tuna poke basically... but I'm sure their poke is flavored differently. The beastie boys was okay for me. I've only had uni 3 times in my life... once was here and the two other times were at two other locations... and they were disgusting. I decided to give it one more try since I assumed it would be fresh here and maybe I'll finally see what all the fuss was all about. It wasn't bad after I ate it. It reminded me of the sea? That's the best I way i can describe it. lol. The beastie boy overall was alright. Minimal seasoning, which I understand since they probably intended for you to taste the uni, fish liver, and the quail egg but I didn't care too much for it. For you purist out there, you may love it more than I did. The white dragon roll was my second favorite dish of the night. Tasty, seasoned well, and fresh. Mmmmm! The Ya Man Roll was pretty good too, nothing out of the ordinary, tasted like something I've had before though. The Yummy Pocket was probably my least favorite item of the night. All I tasted was the sweet tofu skin. The scallops weren't seasoned or something so I didn't really care too much for it, all I could taste was sweet tofu. Finally, we had to order the flaming seabass cause... everyone talks about it! It was nice to see, flavor wise, wasn't bad either. It was a bit too saucey for me, but it still tasted good. Wasn't overcooked even though it was sitting above a flame for a while. Overall, the meal was pretty good. Price is decent for sushi and the rolls are a generous size. Service is good too. Place can get pretty packed since it's not that big but they do allow for you to put your name on the list and they'll call your phone when it's your turn.
author: Johnson S.

description:
Excellent sushi - I always sit at the bar and ask the chefs to order for me.  The only draw back is you leave this place smelling like salmon - when I get home my cats chase after me as if I were their next meal!  
Another draw back is you have to wait... but you usually have to wait at a good restaurant.
author: john s.

description:
Elephant Sushi is our latest FAVORITE sushi place.  We live in the suburb where most of sushi places serve decent but not very authentic (kind with a lot of sauce) sushi.  That is okay, We are not looking for authentic sushi all the time. 

Once in a while we crave for something more authentic and different, and this place definitely fits the bill.  It's not traditional sushi restaurant but in my opinion their dishes give off the similar vibes you would expect from innovative izakaya restaurants in Peninsula and Japan.  

They don't take reservations over the phone, so we had to wait for a good hour, but it was definitely worth the wait.
author: Kay A.

description: Revisiting the once popular elephant sushi to relive the magic now long gone. No more interesting menu fish, inflated sf prices, and, most importantly, no more saki bombs. Fun, meet garbage.
author: Rachel M.

description: HORRIBLE SERVICE! You wait 1 hour 30 minutes to sit down and then they push you to get out of the restaurant as quickly as possible. If I'm paying for extremely expensive sushi and I just waited 1.5 hours to eat, I want to be able to enjoy myself. NOT WORTH IT!
author: Katie T.

description:
Great neighborhood sushi spot. The sushi is fresh, delicious and affordable. I'd highly recommend the ya man roll, double albacore, rainbow roll, chips n dip.

Great sake special too, $2 sake bombs! The chefs are awesome behind the sushi bar, the owner works most nights and he's fantastic. 

The rest of the staff is hit or miss, there have been times where service was okay, and sometimes where it could have been better. 

Either way, best bang for your buck for sushi in the city!
author: Leticia C.

description:
This was by far the most amazing sushi experience of my life. Granted, I have been living in land locked Utah for a little while but I have had sushi in some of the greatest cities in the world and this place was the most unique, the most fresh, the tastiest sushi I've ever had. 

We arrived as it opened and there was already a line. We got the last two seats in the restaurant at the bar and we ordered quickly. The flaming sea bass, the Himalayan trout and the Boom box were my favorite rolls we ordered. 

The service was outstanding from both the server and the people behind the bar. They were friendly, gave great recommendations, and were terrific when we told them we didn't like our first wine selection. They took it back and didn't charge us at all.

This will be my first stop for dinner when returning to San Francisco.
author: Eric J.

description:
Minus one star for the poor time management (we waited an hour when we were told it would be 15-30 minutes for a spot) but the food was flawless. Absolutely delicious, fresh, flavorful food!

If you sit in the right place you can see the dishes being prepared, which is pretty amazing!

Highly recommend this place, but be ready for a wait. 

Be sure to put your name on their wait list.
author: Petrea R.

description:
Waiting for table - they said 45 min (this was at 8:45PM) and we prob waited 20-30 but didn't even notice because we went to the pizza place across the street and grabbed a beer. 

Atmosphere  -  total BRO crowd (meh) but cool interior - smallish, mix of modern and Hawaiian chill. Cool but not stuffy. 

Food - house-made ginger, yummy rolls - white out roll really is awesome and friendly chefs. They were closing when we left so they gave us some delicious sashimi for free. So yum!
author: Amy C.

description:
How have I not discovered this neighborhood gem before! We stumbled into Elephant sushi while walking through Russian Hill late one Sunday afternoon. The restaurant was busy - luckily we were able to sneak two seats at the sushi counter without having to wait. The Himalayan Ocean Trout and Hirame Surprise are a must order! I would have gotten them again had my  boyfriend not wanted to try other items on the menu. The fish was extremely fresh and bright! There was no need to add any additional sauces, everything was exceptionally good just the way they served it.  

Service was good. I would recommend the counter as the people making the dishes were friendly and inviting. They took the time to explain each item served and you could see they took a lit of pride in their work. We also got sake (obviously!) which was served in martini glasses - a little weird, but hey, I'll take it! Can't wait to be back.
author: Elisa P.

description: I tried the spicy trio sashimi bowl. They are known for their sashimi bowls. Spicy trio is $12 ($13.05 with tax) and comes with spicy tuna, spicy scallop, spicy salmon, and avocado. Sashimi bowls also have cucumber, seaweed, and tomato. Pretty good! Light and refreshing meal. Surprisingly filling.
author: Josephine L.

description:
This rating is specifically on the food and since i'm a sushi snob, i'm very particular with my sushi. 

If you like rolls, with interesting flavor combination, YES, go here. If you want authentic, fresh sushi, not sure. Majority of the items I ordered were rolls. They definitely have some creative ideas with their rolls, but honestly, I've had better ones that are cheaper, better taste and quality. What you need to eat here is the beastie boys, it did not disappoint me. It had enough uni and ankimo that blended well without ruining the good flavors of uni and ankimo. 

The rolls I tried were: ya man, giants, flaming seabass and double albacore. 
My personal favorite is the giants roll; the flavor combination of the roll was perfect and I think the salmon was good. I personally think if they added shiso leaf to it, or the flavor of shiso, it would taste much better. For the rest, it felt that something was missing in the flavor or the flavors does not blend at all.

Ya man roll: the pesto was just off and it shouldn't be there at all.
Flaming seabass: overpowering sauce and the fish was ok. what makes this roll special is how it's prepared.
Double albacore: I don't think the fish was fresh, it tasted a bit fishy and I did not like the honey mustard taste on the roll, I personally think that it doesn't blend with the other flavor. 

I personally do not consider this place as one of the best sushi in SF so beware of those reviews that mentions it, because it really is not the best (based on my tastebuds). For the ones who thought flaming seabass and double albacore was good, they do not know what a good sushi is, or never tasted one. 
I would rather go to saru sushi (I think the price range of their food is about the same) for the rolls. Oh, or sushi zone is way better than this place and it's cheaper there too.
But, I would come back to have Beastie boys and if you don't order it, no point of going here.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
OMG this place is yuppie (bourgeois) hell!!

Not only does the food make me gag, horrible warm mushy sushi, the service is lousy and the high pitch screaming of the coifed and pampered clientele made me want to either do heroin right there at my table or slit my wrists. 

I do not recommend.
author: SCOTT L.

description:
Elephant Sushi is not your traditional Japanese sushi place: the focus is less on perfectly fresh fish than inventive and unique rolls, which are still very delicious in their own right. Freshness fortunately doesn't suffer, so it's still worth it. I really liked the Beastie Boys - you get uni, monkfish liver and a little quail egg yolk served gunkan-style. It's very rich, but the rice cuts through the richness some and the ingredients just melts and oozes in your mouth.

The Flaming Seabass was also another excellent showstopper: it's wrapped up in aluminum foil and cooked tableside, so avoid singing your arm hairs/eyebrows. I'm not usually a fan of heavily sauced-up sushi rolls, but this roll was one tasty gimmick with the tobiko topping and sweet/savory sauces.

The Whiteout Roll had a briney taste to it, which I actually liked, but I imagine some people may not like it. I also had the Naked Scallop roll, which was probably the least worthy roll since it was rather bland and I felt like none of the components really served to complement each other.

Overall, the Beastie Boys is a definite must-order - you'll just have to let your imagination guide you for your other choices.
author: Jin C.

description:
Wow I was blown away by this place! Didn't expect much since I usually assume places that specialize in rolls are gimmicky, but Elephant Sushi is a true heavy hitter.

The $2 all day happy hour sake bombs were already a good sign of a great night. When a flaming bowl topped with a roll of their Flaming Seabass came out of the kitchen, we knew the night would be one to remember. 

The Beastie Boy (ankimo, quail egg, and uni) is made for the daring, but tastes mostly like yolk. Still a good thing.

Other standouts: truffle hamachi, Giants roll, Red and White, and the white fish.

Make a reservation, the place is not huge and fills up quickly!
author: Calvin W.

description: Definitely worth the wait. Tricky to get in for more than 2 people. If you bring cash, there may be a shorter wait to sit at the "VIP express" table. Wine bar is next door to sip while you wait. You MUST order the flaming sea bass. They light it on fire and it is infused with a variety of spicy and delicious flavors. Nigiri is great and love the fresh ginger in a mason jar!
author: Jamie L.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night for dinner. Wait wasn't too long for a party of 2. Great service, good sushi, interesting options and reasonably priced. Had a standard avocado/salmon roll and tried the beastie boys (which I thought were just okay). $2 sake bomb is quite a great deal as well!
Would definitely come again to try other menu options, particularly the flaming seabass roll! Mmmm!
author: Siv L.

description: After a rough week for my boyfriend and I, we decided to treat ourselves to some quality sushi. Elephant sushi did not disappoint. The quality of the fish was outstanding, the service was too notch and I LOVED the house made ginger that they served in a jar--I ate about half of it. We will be back!
author: Molly A.

description:
Amazing sushi but be prepared to wait... my average wait time has been an hour and fifteen on weekend nights if I put in my name around 7:30pm. Just go take a walk around Polk - hostess will call you and you can walk over while they clean off the table.

The dishes are unique and diverse and if you get a seat at the chef's bar it's a great atmosphere. I wish the water refills would come around more often but that's my only gripe. It's a tiny restaurant which explains the long wait, but it's a great atmosphere. I want to say it's the best sushi I've had in the Bay. I'd highly suggest this as a date place or even for casual meetups but NOT FOR GROUPS because I will be giving you the evil eye if your giant party takes up half the restaurant.

Love the employees here too - very friendly.
author: Melissa T.

description: Tried to visit Elephant Sushi yet again, would NOT serve party of 8, even after offering to separate into 2 groups of 4. TERRIBLE service! Then asked to get order to go and apparently not something this restaurant does....keep in mind every restaurant in SF delivers or has to go options.  We will take our business to an establishment that actually likes to earn money and serve their clientele. The owners should look into the friendliness of their wait staff as well. Turning down customers when you have 3 open tables on a Saturday evening! FYI- you are in the food service business and word of mouth goes farther than you think. If you can't sit 8 people at least have a to go option....101 in food service, really???
author: J B.

description: Elephant sushi is a very popular place so get there early and wait in line. We arrive about twenty minutes before they opened and then a line started to form. Seating is limited as well. The sushi here is different and traditional as well. Everything we had was very, very good!
author: Kirk M.

description:
This place is the best sushi restaurant that I have been to hands down by far.  We started off with the Omekaze- 18 pieces of fresh assorted, melt-in-your-mouth sashimi. Next, the sashimi salad- big fresh chunks of salmon and tuna topped with roe served over a bed of spinach, heirloom tomatoes, and okra.  We also had to get the Beastie Boys- uni, quail egg, and a piece of sashimi.  Finally, our last order because we couldn't resist- the Himalayan trout served over pink Himalayan rock salt.  Everything that we ordered was delicious, no complaints whatsoever.  I would definitely come back here again even though the worst part of it is the parking.  Parking is terrible, so plan ahead for that.  If i could take away a 1/2 star, it would be solely for the purpose of the difficult parking in the area, otherwise i give them 5 stars.

+ great food
+ great service
+ cozy, casual, dim ambience
- parking, it's terrible!
author: Veronica E.

description:
I'm going to have to just agree with the other reviews of this place. WOW. We waited an hour on a Sunday evening. It was worth the wait. I would wait longer. 

Two things worth mentioning- yum yum pockets are really yummy. Always always always order yum yum pockets. Flaming sea bass is as good as they say. Always always always order the flaming sea bass. 

Very small restaurant, great service, excellent food.
author: Michelle C.

description: This place gets busy on a Saturday night but they are so nice and accommodating! Our waitress recommended the Flaming Sea bass roll. It was lit on fire at our table. This was a really great date night dinner and would be an impressive first date site!
author: Lexie G.

description:
Very good sushi in San Francisco! Located in Russian hill, one of the cutest neighborhoods in the city. The restaurant is intimate and cozy. Perfect for a date night. There is usually always a wait.

We came on a Sunday night and waited about 20 mins. We were seated at a nice table near the window. Ordered the white out roll, flaming seabass, tuna, and another one I can't recall the name of (it had banana on top). All were very good. The price was reasonable. For 4 rolls we spent approx $50 which is a deal in sf. Will definitely come back.
author: Irene R.

description:
So my girlfriend and I decided to eat here before heading back home to Los Angeles and arrived at aprox 5:50 pm on a Thursday. 
If you get here early and ask for a seat for two then I'm sure you will be seated quickly. Reservations are first though. 
I was very pleased with the waitress. She attended us almost as soon as we sat down. 
The food was great
author: Alexia V.

description:
Amazing.

Inventive rolls, high quality fish. It's just really good. I could go on, but that's basically all you need to know.
 
Notes:
Flaming Seabass (roll cooked at your table) isn't really my thing, and feels a bit gimmicky.
Beastie Boys is also gimmicky, but interesting enough to be worth getting the first time you come.
Order of the specials section. Everything is great.
The sashimi may sound boring, but it's delicious.
If there's a wait, put your name down and go to the wine bar down the street.
author: Alex T.

description: What a nice reply from a owner... If I'm looking for cold sushi or beer Safeway has it?  You definitely lost a customer for life.  Kick rocks douche bag.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Whenever there's a long line outside a restaurant, it always sparks some sort of curiosity.  Thus, I'm sad to report that everything was average at best.  The rolls and appetizers were tasty but heavily sauced making it hard to determine the quality of the fish (sushi snobs, this is not the place for you).    The tables were also very cramped together as it's a small space; so don't expect much privacy.  

If you don't want to wait over an hour for a table on the weekends, get in line 15-20 min before they open.
author: Michele L.

description:
I am really mixed on Elephant Sushi.  I've eaten a fair amount of sushi over the years, and food-wise this remains a stand-out, local favorite. The food has been consistently great over 1/2 dozen or so trips, and the fish is melt in your mouth good.  The menu is creative, and the guys behind the sushi bar are friendly and knowledgable.  Prices are extremely reasonable.  

Elephant also used to have extremely friendly and helpful staff. In my recent experiences, however, this was dramatically changed.  The last time I tried to eat at Elephant, I was turned away- told they had "obviously" closed their wait list a full hour before published close time. That's fine if you take reservations, but they don't, and no one answered the phone when I called to check on wait.  Don't make a customer show up to be turned away at the door, and certainly don't be rude when you do it. Poor form. 

Tonight I gave Elephant another chance and went back with a friend in from out of town.  Expecting a long wait (per usual), we went to Bacchus next-door for a glass of wine (always a good plan).  When the hostess called to say our table was ready, she made sure to tell us to race over, or she would give our seats away and take us off the wait list, no exceptions.  I returned to Elephant while my buddy cleared his tab, and was told to wait outside like I had just violated the law.  She then refused to seat me without both of us there in front of her. There are so many ways she could have handled this without being rude / mean.  Going out to dinner is supposed to be fun...

Later in the evening the same hostess decided to drop her rain cloud on us again by asking me to "slide my chair in so servers could get by."  This was two hours into our meal, with not a comment from the actual servers, and enough room for a linebacker to pass between me and the guy seated behind.

Our waitress was dramatically nicer, but had limited understanding of the menu- she recommended what she thought was "popular," and was overly attentive- asking what felt like every few minutes if we wanted anything more or the check.

This makes me sad, because I am local to Elephant, and when they first opened, they were super nice and accommodating. Combined with fantastic food, it was a really special place.  Now the great food is colored by service which is close to the low bar in my years in San Francisco.  The food is worth a visit, but if you are in for the experience, look elsewhere.  Hopefully Elephant will fix this and return to the friendly, fun place it once was.
author: Ben M.

description: Trendy sushi fusion place in the heart of Russian Hill. The place suits the neighborhood and is filled with those in their 20's and 30's. Good reggae music was playing while the chefs turned out sushi at a fast pace. The nigiri was fresh and very good. I tried the salmon and yellowtail. The yummy pocket appetizer was good too. I found the Ya Man roll to be a little heavy with the oil sauce. Considering a small app, a roll and 4 pieces of nigiri set me back $40, I think yelp needs to adjust their $$ rating to $$$ or $$$$.
author: Jared B.

description:
MUST ORDER : Flaming Sea Bass ,  IT IS !!! $16, Unique concept of wrapping the sushi in foil and then roasting it in flames on the table before being served to eat. Every bite of this dish will blow your mind!! This dish will keep us coming back again.

Double Albacore rolls, $15 -  Great taste! Came with 8pcs. 
Boom Box - with ripe bananas, not of my liking. SKIP!

Service - Fast and attentive.
Ambiance - Modern, small and intimate. 

Price - Total bill for 3 dishes, a martini and 2 beers came to $60 (excluding tip). 

Noted, next time would try the beastie boys, Himalayan trout on salt rock and white out.
author: Payal B.

description: Great sushi and atmosphere! Very small and cozy so ideal for a date night. Had the red&yellow and the Ya Man rolls. More than enough for two people with light appetites. The portions for nigiri are REALLY big too. Make sure you get there early and do not put your name down then leave, the hostess will seat you faster if you stay near the door. She was very sweet and asked if we wanted tea to warm up in the cold. Be patient and don't pester her, you'll be rewarded for good behavior! It's a popular place, but worth the 30-45 minute wait for dinner.
author: Zel H.

description:
Ok... I admit when I first got there, I was a bit turned off when I walked in at 5:37 only to be told they were not open till 6pm, and was kicked out...after driving 2 hours to meet with family, needless to say, I was a little annoyed...

But I will say that despite my first impression, their sushi, bar none is amazing!  Fresh, unique, and utterly delectable.  

Their butterfish was my favorite... Is there such a thing as having too much?  Surely not, can't wait till the next time...  We will be back soon!
author: Del S.

description:
Amazing Amazing Amazing!!! I love this neighborhood Sushi place. They dont take reservations but the wait is worth it, I promise =) You can actually put your name down and head up to the small wine bar right next door....

Elephant Sushi is a very cozy, intimate setting and a great spot for a casual date or with friends.

Here are some of my recommendations: 
Hamachi Truffle
Blue Fin Tuna
Flaming Sea Bass
Godzilla

Everything is amazing but the above are my must tries! $2 sake bombs during happy are a deal .
author: Sepi N.

description:
The BEST.
We started with "Godzilla" (albacore tuna wrapped shrimp tempura, fried garlic, chili and ponzu roll) , then "White Out" (hamachi, avocado, topped with seared butter fish and ponzu roll) and just had to try the "Himalayan Trout" (NZ ocean trout cured on Himalyan pink salt rock, green onion, Spanish chili, garlic ponzu and house basil oil sashimi). The service was great, and the fish was superb. There's a handwritten (customer) sign that says "Elephant is the shit!!" aside from a poor choice of adjective, I couldn't agree more.
A must try when you're in the city!
author: Jasmine K.

description:
Wow. I have a lot to say about this place. 

I came here a few months back and absolutely loved it. The salmon sashimi is to die for and there are several pretty tasty rolls and apps. Beer is cheap and the setting is intimate and nice.

Unfortunately the past two times I have come here it has progressively gotten much worse. It has taken my gf and I couple of tries but we will NOT RETURN. This is the typical type of place in San Francisco that attracts people that follow other people. The servers develop an understanding that no matter what they will meet their quota and therefore disconnect from providing good service or communication. Hopefully the following real life scenarios will help relay this picture.

The second time we ate there we ordered all our food and were abruptly informed that we needed to eat quickly because it was last call. Kind of awkward but we got the point. My gf and I both work in restaurants so this is completely understandable. However, our server may have had a communication barrier so she came across a little harsh and condescending. Once again, I was willing to be understanding.

This last time I went was about a week or so ago. After a fairly short wait I was seated with my gf and other buddy. Our server must have been new to the industry because she kept forgetting our order. For example, we started off by putting in our order for beer/sake, salmon sashimi and the flaming sea bass. We waited awhile, received our beer and sake, and then it happened...nothing!

After ample amount of time (15 more minutes) we decided to place our entree order. 15 minutes later our entree appeared. Note we still haven't heard or received anything from our first initial order. 

Meanwhile there are 5-6 sushi chefs "hard at work" five feet away from us. Lets keep in mind there are only 10 or so two-person tables in this entire restaurant. We reminded her and she quickly disappeared back onto the floor. 

At this point we are all a little annoyed but we knew the sashimi would be worth it. It finally came, thank god! It was as delicious as I remembered it and of course we wanted another order. This time it showed up almost immediately. I know you are probably wondering wtf is going on over there. Yup, me too...

Finally it came time to pay. The 3 of us put our cards down and our server unconfidently informed us we could only split it 2 ways. Now I know how annoying it is to split cards. I have been serving for years and it is definitely one of my pet peeves. However, this server made so many mistakes it seemed audacious to create more problems with us. We were informed we could contact the owners. The whole line of staff were looking at us and we could see them talking under their breaths with condescending smiles. All of the sudden we could palpate the animosity being directed towards us. I felt so disrespected. One of the most unprofessional groups of staff I have ever seen. I have never heard of this sort of situation in my life. 

The take home message is this group of staff collectively don't care about their patrons. They care about turning and burning you. 

If you have any respect for yourself, partner or friends you WILL NOT give these bigots the benefit of the doubt. After all, there are plenty of sushi restaurants in San Francisco that will treat you with respect (even if they do make a couple mistakes). Keep in mind it is just sushi, there are countless combinations of delicious fish dishes and beverages here in the bay area. Why add the taste of disrespect and neglect to your palate when you could be treated with genuine respect?

After all, sushi is a representation of Japanese culture; a tradition based on respect and order. Elephant sushi has lost sight of its original aim and for these reasons they have been CHOPPED! 

I hope this post helps you to learn from my mistakes, there are countless excellent sushi bars right around the corner...
author: Erronious M.

description:
Ahhhh...sushi! We went back for our 2nd time last night to celebrate my fiance's birthday because, after all, we'd been dreaming about it since our first visit 4 months ago. Clearly it was far too long to wait-pretty sure the restaurant owners realized they were "giving away" too much fish for the price and have significantly paired down the portions, particularly with the Himalayan Trout sashimi...alas, still the best damn sushi we've ever had and we will be back! Though I will say, they we're quite generous with the shavings of truffle on both the Hamachi Truffle and Walu Carpaccio sashimi. 
Only this time we won't wait 4 months. Our birthdays are over but maybe we can celebrate Halloween with Elephant Sushi!?!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Good inventive dishes here with pretty good fish.  The chef special plates set the menu apart, while the normal sushi and rolls are good but not great.  The white out roll, apparently the most popular item here, is overrated and has a weird fishy bbq taste.  but the hamachi truffle appetizer is insane.  also also nice to find Sapporo on tap.

Pro tip - hit Swensen's after for some original thin mint!
author: Josh P.

description:
Elephant sushi is not an authentic sushiya. It's fusion. Pretty damn good fusion too.

There are no Japanese chefs, the decor is over-zen, and the fish selection is limited. There are rolls golare, and very few a person eating nigiri. It's difficult to order incrementally at the counter, they rather you order everything up front I suppose, but I insisted and they allowed it. 

On the other hand, the fish was good. Everything was modern, elegant, and surprisingly yummy. Expect to spend about 100-120$ for 2 people. The beastie boy gunkan (ankimo, uni, shiso, and quail egg) is excellent, don't miss that. The butterfish and shaved truffle was great as well. You can pass on the flaming sea bass roll if you don't like hot, heavy, and rich rolls.

As far as fusion goes, Elephant Sushi is pretty damn good. It doesn't get an authentic earmark from me, so don't expect anything Japanese.
author: Grayson K.

description:
Let me keep this short, sweet, and simple.  

GET:

Omakase - Get 1 order for every 2 persons.  DO NOT USE wasabi or soy.  Usually the Omakase is so fresh, that you don't need it, and really allows you to taste the fish.   After you you tried all the sashimi, order more of your fave after.

White Out Roll- TRUST. ITS A MUST. I don't care for rolls, I like my sashimi, and none of the bs of rice. But I will get weak in the knees for this roll.  I once ordered 3 of these rolls to be shared among 2 people + the other 6 things I ordered.. true story. 

SKIP:

Flaming Roll- Sure its pretty, and has shiny fire. Such cavemen we are. But why eat a cooked roll when the best thing about a roll here is the raw fish??!  

Boombox- Banana overpowers EVERYTHING. It was a banana roll.. I can get that at TJ's for $0.19...

Beastie Boys- I LOVE monk fishliver, sea urchin, and quail eggs. But when its all in one giant piece, and the only non-messy way to eat it is by fitting this ALL in one bite.. You barely are able to taste what you just shoved.  Trust, get the uni+quail as one order, and the ankimo as another. 


**Note: I really wish the sake pricing was a little more inlined... Nigori Sake @ $25?? Most places price them at $10-$13... (pssst its like $5 at the Japanese/Korean markets).  Due to this, I stick to beer, but its just not the same.
author: Deanna T.

description:
I write for a living so very, very few things in life render me speechless.

This astounding sushi restaurant, however, allows me to utter only one simple, meaningful word: INCREDIBLE.

Elephant Sushi is, by far, the best sushi I have ever had - coast to coast.

From the hostess (with whom we conversed and made a reservation on the phone and who was super sweet when we arrived) to our server, Emmanuel, whose knowledge of the menu was impeccable, this was just a wonderful, sublime, delectable evening all around.

We shall return. As soon as possible.

FYI: Don't miss out on the flaming sea bass or the walu carpaccio. I've never had sushi with truffle oil - this should be on a master bucket list somewhere. Not to be missed in a lifetime!!!!
author: Jessica C.

description:
I absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE elephant sushi. I really like the fresh scallop topped with fresh wasabi and Yuzu. Sooooo good. Thinking about it makes me drool.

By far one of the best sushi restaurant in San Francisco.
author: jessica t.

description: I'm disappointed that I am writing this, as elephant sushi was my favorite sushi restaurant in SF and I live one block away so I would frequent it quite often. I went to dinner with three friends a few weeks ago and we all experienced the worst service we have ever had in our life. Which is a lot to say for four people who've all had their share of bad experiences. It started with our waitress being generally rude and unhelpful when we were trying to ask a question or when it took her 20 mins to give us the bottle of wine we ordered. I have celiac disease so I am on a strict gluten free diet. Usually elephant sushi is great and can make most rolls gf with no problem. I ordered the famous chips and dip, but always get it without the chips. This time it came on the chips (which it has before) so I kindly asked to send it back (since I had explained to the waitress that I have a gluten allergy and have celiac and to inform the chef). She then takes it back in a fuss without apologizing. When she bring its back, I start to eat it and can tell the taste is off. I look at the bottom of the pile of spicy tuna and there are pieces of pita chip crumbs. I then ask to send it back again and she comes back the third time saying they've sold out and is horribly rude and walks away. It being sold out isn't true because most of their rolls have spicy tuna in it (including ones we ordered). Finally our meal comes and all seems to be ok. When she gives us the bill I ask for the other spicy tuna appetizer to come off our bill. We had ordered two to share between 4 people - since it's so good. She gets in a huff again and says she need to call the owner out. I was happy to hear this because I've never had someone be so rude to me about my celiac and so unapologetic if something was mistaken. Especially because at that point I had a high probability of getting sick later. The "owner" (still don't know if he is - was also a sushi chef that night) comes out and is even ruder. He said he was the one who took it off the chips and put it on my plate and told the waitress to then lie that they sold out because he was too frustrated to make another one. He then spent the next 5 minutes explaining that if we ate the food then we need to pay for it and couldn't have cared less that we had terribly rude service the entire night or that he had served me food that can make me ill. Multiple other things I'm not even taking the time to describe were said. Mind you, we had spend about $200 and were asking for a $10 appetizer to be taken off the meal because of our terrible experience during that course and I was a loyal customer who has recommended multiple people to go there.  He gets so fed up and eventually says "fine! We will do whatever you want! I'm going home!" And storms off. The waitress then comes and drops off the bill. I've never not tipped 20% - even for bad bad service. While debating, I signed, but had the tip blank. The waitress comes over and rips the receipt out of my hand. I call back to her and say I wasn't ready and she says "you think I'm expecting ANYTHING from you!!???" And then I asked for the receipt again and the huffs back and says - "you think I'm going to steal from your bank account????" - at that point, I left no tip and we all walked to our next destination so we could vent and cool off from this horrible situation we were just in. Nothing I could type could describe how terrible the experience was, but I'd warn ANYONE WITH A STRICT GLUTEN FREE DIET TO NOT COME HERE. I've never been treated so poorly and this was worse than a waiter once listing off issues I could possible have when asking what happens when I eat gluten. It has taken me some time to write this because I was so upset, but needed to make the time to. No ones deserves to get treated so poorly so sending this as a warning to anyone who wants to come here! #RIPnakedscalloproll
author: Natalie C.

description:
I had dinner here a couple of weeks ago with two of my friends, and it was just our lucky day - the other party of three was not all present so we got their table! within 1 minute of walking into the restaurant!  SCORE!

The food - fresh and creative!  This is the type of place where different and unexpected flavors and ingredients are meshed together, so ordering sashimi was not high on my list.  But bc I wanted to try everything, I did happen to have the sake sashimi and it was like butter!  I really wish I could remember what else I had but I don't remember the names...but I basically made my orders based off of the Yelp photos!  So thank you, Yelpers!

I hear the wait can be really long at times...but good thing there are things to do in the area.  I'm sure the wine bar across the street is benefiting off the long waits at Elephant Sushi :)
author: Lisa Marie R.

description: I went to Elephant on a Sunday evening and was able to get a table without a wait even though it was a pretty full house. Service was quick and polite. Tables are close together but not too crowded (I did end up in conversation with the folks right next to us). All the rolls we tried were delicious and beautifully presented. The highlight was, by far, the house-made pickled ginger. So good! And the pricing was pretty reasonable for the city, too.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I admit, abashedly, that I've waited 3 hours to eat at Elephant Sushi. Yes, it's true. They don't offer reservations so if you wanna eat here, be prepared to wait - especially if your party is greater than 2. They only have 3 different seating options if you have a group: 1) small table in the front that seats 4, 2) the sushi bar, 3) a table in the back that usually gets shared between parties. The restaurant itself is pretty small, but very cute - I dig the atmosphere big time and in a utopian Corrina-restaurant-world, all restaurants would be something like Elephant Sushi. The service is A+++; I've never had a bad experience here, albeit waiting 3 hours even. The food is very tasty too - I recommend the Flaming Seabass, Giants roll, and the $2 sake bombs ($2!!!). 

Now the wait... it's awful. At least, it CAN be. If you don't mind eating really early or really late, I would recommend coming 10-15 min before opening or closer to closing time if you want to minimize wait. When you're waiting, do yourself a favor and head over to Stones Throw and grab some tasty drinks and apps (and say 'hi' to Jason - head chef extraordinaire). Even though I love this place, I would not bring a bigger group here (i.e. more than 2 people). 

Roy C. did good.  Fantastic date spot ;)!
author: Corrina S.

description:
One of the sushi places that I visited during my ongoing sushi spree. 
This one is my favorite so far hands down! Their sashimi is nothing but amazing. Best sashimi I've tried so far. They have the best food presentation out of all the sushi places in this price range that I've been to. 
Place is very small and is very packed. They only take reservations for their opening hour and they drop your reservation if you are more than 10 mins late. We came at 611pm (had a reservation at 6pm) and had to get on the wait list. The wait was about 45mins. It was definitely worth it though!
author: Luba Y.

description:
Hello 2015! I would LOVE to start the year off with 5 stars...and here it is! Elephant Sushi! It is located in Russian Hill so it is a bit of a hike but it is worth it. There is a long wait and it can get crowded because it is awesome, delicious but also small.  It is a quaint place and there were two small chairs for people to wait outside. 

It was date night with my boyfriend...whaaaaat!? Yes, I got me one of dem...but I promise that's not why this place was 5 stars...although the company was fabulous :) 

Hamachi Truffle - I can eat this all day, every day! There was this taste that just encompassed my soul. I think it was the truffle. Or the Hamachi? Or the perfect marriage between the two. 

Beastie Boys - Yes, and YES! Intergalactic! This was so good. I'm a sucker for uni and the boyfriend enjoyed the raw egg. Again, a perfect marriage. You definitely have to have a true foodie tongue to appreciate this. Not that I have one, live scorpion still freak me out...

Lastly, we had the flaming sea bass and that was good. Not as good as the other ones but it was definitely festive. I can't wait to come back! The service was excellent and the sake pairings were awesome as well. 

Perfect restaurant with someone that likes to eat and drink as much as me! Cheers to 2015!
author: Leena B.

description: Really good sushi. Make sure you call ahead and show up before 8:30, as the kitchen closes at 10 and the line can be an hour.
author: Ben B.

description:
1. Don't get the Hello Kitty Martini.  I don't know why I did.  I was kind of expecting it to be "cute," but I should have known not to order a martini from a sushi restaurant.

2. My friend wanted to only order shrimp tempura, but for some reason, the chefs refused to do it.  Instead, they gave her a tempura roll... without telling her that they couldn't just make shrimp tempura for her.  Weird?  Are the rolls premade or something?

3. The specialty rolls - no doubt - are Americanized, saucy and delicious.  It's expensive, but a lot better than Sushi Rapture and Sushi Rock.  I guess you're kind of paying for the "trendy" atmosphere too or something.  Whatever.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Overrated. Trying to be too fancy with the sauces. The sushi should speak for itself. Flaming Sea Bass is $20 worth of bland. Mounds of mushy rice, c'mon now.  It is what it is. Would not recommend to the locals.
author: Mason T.

description:
There's one other highly anticipated spot I am dying to try, but Elephant Sushi is my favorite sushi place in SF so far.

The line is usually long so I like to sneak over to Union Larder for drinks (but even that now has a long wait).  Once seated, I can honestly say everything is pretty damn good.  You won't go wrong with any selection.  My favorite though is the Hamachi Truffle and Hirami Surprise.  I think the flavors and texture mix so well together.  

Cheers.
author: Bert N.

description:
Had high expectations for this restaunrant since we were not from a city located by the ocean (we're from Montreal) with fresh fish in abundance that can be easily acquired. 
Went to this place on suggesting of a friend from the area. Went around 8h30 on a Thursday night, knew about the wait from previous Yelp reviews so planned accordingly (found a place near by in advance to grab a drink). Waited 45 mins in total to be seated.
Felt a bit pressured to order as we sat down as the waitress came to us a few times in a very short interval. 
Finally ordered the hamachi truffle, blue fin tuna and beastie boys to start off.
Hamachi truffle was disapointing as didn't quite ge tthe truffle taste as I was hoping for.
Blue fin tuna was also disapointing as the slices were so thin. In my opinion,you need a good chunk of blue fin tuna so actually appreciated it's buttery texture. Cut it too thin and just tasted like regular tuna.
The beastie boys was quite good however, a bomb of richness and flavour in one bite! 

Continued with the red and yellow roll (not memorable at all as I had to look up what I had ordered in the menu...) and the flaming seabass. The seabass was delicious, rish and creamy sauce served warm. 
We also had the white out roll but I can't remember what it tasted like to give a constructive feedback. 

Being the bottomless pits we are, we were still hungry after this and wanted to order some more rolls. However, we were advised that the kitchen had run out of rice for the night and only sashimis and salads were available. Disapointed, but still hungry, we opted to try their mix sashimi plate (nothing out of the ordinanry from any other sushi joint, can't say it was fresher than what we are used to back home) and the anago (which was served without rice but very tasty nonetheless). 

Overall, it was a enjoayble experience given we were on vacation and got to enjoy a rice stroll in Russian hill. Some of the dishes were quite good (beastie boys, flaming seabass and anago), but the rest were just ok. Maybe it's just us who were too hyped out about getting the 'freshiest sushi ever' but it was not any different from the places we go to back home in terms of fish quality.
author: Victoria X.

description: Awesome and innovative sushi! Always busy though, so make a reservation or be prepared to wait.
author: Kelsey G.

description: Returned to Elephant Sushi and had an excellent experience.  Great waiter who understood Celiac disease and made sure everything was gluten-free.  Awesome sushi.  Wish they had edamame.
author: Ashley F.

description:
They now are statistically relevant. I've visited more than once and each time they never cease to amaze me.  

Sashimi - amazing cuts and quality.  Mixed in with the right amount of flavors.  Equates to a Chopin symphony in your mouth - subtle and stupendous 

Sushi - just so much fun and innovative things they put together.  Always changing.  Ever grateful for that - because this is the backbone of the meal for us big guys.  

OMG MOMENT - bestie boy!!!! Nuff said. 

Hospitality - makes us want to get down on one knee and ask them to marry us each time.  

Saki - good.  But hey I'm here for the sushi.  

Like an elephant I never forget each and every experience you guys give me.  Till next time.
author: R P.

description:
I can't even begin to tell you everything that I ate while I was at Elephant Sushi. The meal included so much sporadic ordering, so many freebies/"try this" from the chef and staff that I think it's very possible we chomped down on half of the menu offerings. However, i can lend the following tips:

(1) They are closed on Mondays and Tuesdays. They don't serve lunch.
(2) YOU MUST SIT AT THE BAR BECAUSE THE SUSHI CHEF IS AWESOME.
(3) The Flaming Sea Bass is good, but don't pass up the White Out roll. It was my absolute favorite.
(4) Ask the chef to recommend something, he won't disappoint.

 If I had to pick a "favorite" food, sushi would probably be it. That said, this is honestly the best sushi that I've ever had in my life...and I eat a lot of the stuff. Although this is a small establishment that seems to get a bit crowded, every member of the staff is nice and extremely helpful. If you're in the area, or just visiting San Francisco, I'd highly recommend trying this place out. You can thank me later. And for Crissssssake, sit at the bar!
author: Carol B.

description:
Service: 5
Food: 4.5
Decor: 4

The service was personable and welcoming.  I really like the sushi/Mongolian infusion with some reggae music in the background. 

You have to try the Flaming sea bass, Himalayan trout on a salt rock, and the white out. 

Don't leave until you try it.
author: Bill J.

description:
Very good rolls. Most memorable is the flaming sea bass for obvious reasons (it cooks in a fire on a plate in front of you!). The whole ordeal makes it a nice date spot.

When I dined at Elephant Sushi, the Uni was quite fresh. I was a bit dissapointed that they did not have my fish here (mackerel). I wasn't able to ask if it was because they rotate their fish in and out or if they don't have usually.

Will definitely come back!
author: Jeff M.

description: We loved the flaming sea bass so much, kept ordering more! So many cool and creative rolls for the adventurous sushi eater!!!
author: Katie E.

description: I'm surprised how good the reviews are...there are way better sushi places in SF.  Maybe it's just a Russian Hill thing?  Had the hawaiian poke which I initially thought was a mistake bc it looked like a veggie dish with lots of red sauce.  Then we saw some pieces of fish.  Definitely not poke and it didn't even taste good.  The white out was good, the ocean trout nigiri was excellent, and the flaming sea bass was flavorful but not exactly sushi.  I think I prefer more traditional sushi places that don't put gobs of goopy sauce over their fish. Also the pickled ginger tasted off. And to top off a mediocre meal, the waitress spilled soy sauce all down my white jacket. Not cool.
author: Debbie L.

description:
So first- I have not eaten here! 

Second- the reason for my review and "A-OK" rating is for their very strange customer service when I have attempted to go to this establishment for sushi.

this place is always BUSY...good for them! So I have tried three times to eat here and have been greeted by a not so nice but not completely unpleasant person. This last time took the cake. We arrived at 8:15PM on a weekday, they are open until 10pm. No one was waiting for seating however there was this perfect little table sitting in the window with two empty seats. the person tells us they have their "express VIP" table ready if we liked. I asked what this means.... she said that its the same as the other tables but we would have to pay with cash??? Why would cash payment be any faster than running a credit card, in fact I would say cash transactions are much slower than credit cards. What If I was paying with rolls of change and two dollar bills.... I think this is crazy and makes no sense to hold a table for cash buyers. This mystery table has been sitting empty on each of my three visits.
author: Brook M.

description: Truly one of the best sushi ever! Not only the raw fish was super fresh, the service was incredible. It really made a difference in our dining experience. Wish we have anything like this in Toronto. This sushi is simple superb.
author: Geek T.

description: Called to make a reservation for two on a Saturday and so glad I did because this place got packed quick! Everything we ordered was perfectly fresh and delicious. The staff was tentative and super friendly. My favorites included the cheap $2 sake bombs and the Himalayan trout. There are a few cons about this place: 1. I really wanted to try their famously known Beastie boy but they didn't have uni that night:( 2. Tables are set uncomfortably close to one another due to the lack of space. I will definitely come back to try their Beastie boy and hopefully I have better luck next time.
author: Sherry P.

description: Favorite sushi place ever! And that says a lot since I am from Hawaii and been to Japan before! The white out and ya men are a must try and the sashimi salad is also really good. I love how they have an all day happy hour with martinis for only $5. Must must try. Worth the wait.
author: Taissa C.

description: Tasty sushi but sadly I watched this place serve a customer a dangerous allergen after repeatedly and explicitly promising not to :(
author: Jon F.

description: Such a great sushi spot hidden in the gem that is Hyde Street! My fiancé and I ate at Elephant Sushi last week and it was totally worth the two hour wait! Although we had to wait in the cold, windy street, the reward of eating such fresh sushi was well worth it. We tried the Chips n' dip for an appetizer and it was even better than typical chips and salsa at any restaurant! This was the best combination of spicy poke and chips and salsa! A must have! We also tried the Uni Nigiri and the  the New Zealand Trout Nigiri which was also great! We finished our meal with the flaming sea bass which was not just a meal but also entertainment! Wonderful date night location, wait not so much fun and estimate of wait time also not so true to reality! Only downfall, but will be back to try out more menu standouts!
author: Isabel F.

description: Totally worth the wait time!  Our uber driver recommended this place while dropping us at another place. We decided to try it and we're happy we did. The sushi was delicious and fresh. Definitely a must try!!
author: Leah H.

description:
I literally have no idea where the 5 star people typically eat sushi in San Francisco, but let me provide a little counterpoint to all the rave reviews.

One of my friends is in town and I wanted to show him how great the sushi in SF is.  I called up my standard sushi spots but everything was over booked.  So I decided to turn to Yelp to see what other options were available, hoping to find a new spot.  

This place showed up with 4.5 stars and I figured, o.k., this has to be the best place ever!  It's anything but.  

After being seated it took 10 minutes for our server to notice we were sitting there.  We literally had to reach out at her to find out who was going to serve us.  We ordered our food, which took another 10 or 15 minutes to come out.  First, they brought out my girlfriend's sushi roll without ours.  She had trouble ordering a california roll because apparently they don't have it on the menu (despite being able to create Rainbow Rolls which are effectively California Rolls with fish on top).

Anyways, they brought out their "flaming" sushi roll which is all for show.  You have to watch your sushi cook for 5 minutes on the table when all you really want to do is eat the sushi because you have an empty stomach.   After you unravel the metal wrapping surrounding the sushi roll, you find a sushi roll which looks like a combination of eggs, bacon, hot sauce, and who knows what else.

As you try to reach in with your chopsticks to pick up the roll that is extremely unappetizing to look at, you find out that the sushi is soft and soup-like.  It's so soft that it crumbles as you grab on to it, resulting in a mess all over your table.  

The most significant problem with this place is that the fish was not fresh at all.  Between waiting 10 minutes or longer for each order to come out, the horrible fish, unexpected hot sauce on the sushi that wasn't described on the menu, the inability of the servers to figure out where to put plates (answer: on the table), and the server's lack of knowledge about sushi, this place is horrible.  

Seriously: don't eat here.
author: Nick O.

description: Insanely good! That's all you need to know! The double albacore, flaming seabass and Ya man roll are some of the best sushi I've ever had. If you don't like mouth organism of amazingness then go to Panda Express!
author: Britney O.

description:
What an absolutely charming and cute neighborhood sushi restaurant admist the bustling Hyde in Russian Hill. There are less than 10 tables in the entire restaurant, most of which are two seaters, which adds to the coziness of it all. When making the reservation, request for the two seater by the window as you'll receive the quintessential San Franciscan view of Hyde St. The interior is dimly lit and aiming for a more modern-rustic flair. 

I'm usually a specialty roll kinda gal when it comes to sushi and I'm wary with sashimi and the like. However, I tried literally everything from sashimi-based orders and nigiri to full fledged house rolls because every single dish was to die for. My personal favorite is a tie between the Flaming Sea Bass Roll and the Hamachi Truffle Appetizer. 

The Sea Bass roll is served to you on a flaming platter inside an aluminum foil and all the hoopla about this is accurate. It's coated in layers of cream & sauces and wrapped around with fresh and deliciously flamed sea bass. Definitely a must-get order if you're dining here. As someone who isn't a huge fan of raw fish, I completely devoured the Hamachi truffle appetizer. It's fresh and cured so finely that it melts with the texture of butter in your mouth. And the accompanying sauce opens the natural flavor of the dish even more. I also enjoyed the beasty boys uni house specialty dish - it's creamy, has egg yolk and something that looks like tofu in it. Sounds like an ecclectic mix but tastes like it was made for each other. 

So whether you're a fan of the cooked fishies or simply love the raw ones, Elephant Sushi has a wide quality selection for you in a unpretentious and casual ambiance. Consider it for your next sushi adventure! 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
So I have been checking out the Russian Hill area more and more lately and of course I had heard of Elephant Sushi from multiple people and knew I had to give it a shot. So yes all the reviews are correct in that this place has the longest line ever when you show up with no reservations. They do take reservations but its only for a very specific period of time so if you want to avoid all the waiting, there is an option for you. The surrounding area is a nice neighborhood and the interior of the restaurant is no different. It is definitely on the small side hence the wait but the décor is nice. I will say that given it's a tiny place, its definitely on the louder side for a restaurant but that's just indicative of the place being filled up so quickly because the food is solid. 

I thought this place overall had great rolls and different combination ideas for the sushi. I was pretty pleased but let me not get too ahead of myself. We obviously ordered the hot sake (how could you not) and started firing through food orders. We ordered the Flaming Sea Bass roll, Hamachi truffle, beastie boys, and the White out roll. This place first starts you off with some house made ginger which is pretty delish. We received the Hamachi first which was a solid performer... probably not the best ive had but definitely worth the nod. The White out roll came out next which is really solid. Its very simple and fresh but just absolute solid dish. The Flaming Sea Bass roll was next and of course the presentation was fun to watch. I really did enjoy this roll but the sauces and everything was a bit too much for me personally. With that said its definitely something I would order again but simply have my counterpart take more of it down. Finally the beastie boys... which I must warn is really for those who love Uni I feel. I am a big fan of uni and the combination that they topped this off was just a great treat. If you are not a Uni fan however, I would recommend something else.

All in all, another solid sushi joint in SF and a spot I have already hit up a few times since going my first time. I look forward to going again but just not that line.
author: Dan M.

description: From the buttery beastie boys, the fiery red dragon, to the perfect finishing white out. Every bite was delicious. Ya know this place is a keeper when the seafood is fresh, and the ginger is homemade. Sit at the bar, it's the best seat in the house.
author: Jac T.

description: We came to the restaurant right when it opened and asked to be seated with one person of our party missing. The host rudely explained that we could not sit down and order appetizers and drinks while we waiting for our other party. We explained to her that she would be here shortly and she told us we were out of luck and that she'd put us on a list even with all the tables in there being empty. I came here based on a recommendation and will not be back due to her obnoxious behavior. This review has nothing to do with the quality of food or the restaurant itself. The hospitality at this place was atrocious.
author: Tiana N.

description: This sushi was so good I daydream about it regularly. Just so fresh and nicely prepared. Believe the hype.
author: Jessica V.

description: Lovely little sushi spot, the wait was a little long but the food was worth it. If the wait is a little more than half an hour go across the street to union larder and have some wine and cheese and craft beer to get you drunk and in the mood. Upon getting the call from the receptionist, the server Ziggy sat us and promptly served out sake bombs. She was the best and a really helpful server for first time patrons. The food was fresh and the service was phenomenal. We're really glad we got to have our 3rd year anniversary dinner here!
author: Neil A.

description: The food was good, but it didn't blow me away as I had expected after reading about this place among popular food articles. We got there before they opened and a small group of people had already formed so I immediately felt like I made a good decision joining the crowd. We were seated with the first round of diners and the service was really great. The space is pretty small - around 10 tables or so plus a small bar area. Be warned though: the tables are tiny! I'm a petite gal and I felt like I had no room to eat. The food is served on plates that take up more space than necessary...Typical sushi prices and presentation - nothing really won me over so I doubt I'd return.
author: Jenny W.

description:
What a fantastic spot, and right down the block from me too! 

I was aghast at the closing of Sushi Groove (occupied the space previously) and the implications that would have for the quality of semi-casual dining / sushi in my neighborhood (less competition for Okoze, surrounded by high-end restaurants, etc etc)....but I'm so thrilled to have Elephant Sushi here (its much, much better)!  This is probably one of the top 2-3 sushi places I've been to in the city (its peers are: Zushi Puzzle, Okoze, and Akiko's)

Its a fantastic cozy spot with a great ambience (though it does smell a little, and Im guessing this has to do with the remodel + fish -- please fix this) 

My picks off the menu:
1. Hamachi Truffle appetizer - hamachi in truffle oil, sprinkled with slices of fried garlic. My friend and I were blown away with the quality of this dish 

2. Sea Bass Roll - a sushi roll wrapped in Chilean sea bass and brought to the table in a flaming plate, inside aluminum foil. Once the flames die down, we were pleasantly surprised with a flame-grilled sea bass and flanking the sushi roll -- and it was DELISH

3. Walu Sashimi - this fish was so rich, tender, and savory that it didn't feel like fish at all; rather, it tasted like game hen or chicken. A fabulous sashimi dish for those of us disinclined towards to the straight up raw meat 

4. Himalayan Trout - I'm not one for sashimi, but the way this meat was cured (with himalayan rock salt and garlic ponzu among other things) made it simply excellent

5. Albacore Tuna Roll - the hint of honey mustard and the plentiful meat in this dish makes it savory with a little kick - love this. 

6. They made us an ice cream sushi dessert that was just mind blowing - probably one of the top 5 desserts I've had in the city 

The service is friendly and very accommodating (thank you for all that iced water ;) ), a bit overwhelmed though (probably one of their first Friday nights). Overall, great staff!!

I am so sold on this place that I actually suggested it for a friend's birthday dinner and I will be there tonight again. Can't wait!
author: Meghana D.

description:
Came here for my birthday and it was amazing. The best sashimi i've ever had in my LIFE! 


Tip: come early or else you'll have to wait forever. The 5 stars is for the food, not the service as they are quite strict and rude about their weird rules.
author: Jessica Z.

description: I wolud give this place a four and half star. Small place stuffed with couples, and the vibe here is great for friends too. Sushi are great but the waiters are always busy. Beastie boys is a must-have for uni fans, too fishy taste for me. Flaming sea bass is the best dish, comes with a bowl with flaming liquid and the sushi roll wrapped in tinpaper hanging on the edge of the bowl. Would definitely go to this place again if I visit San Francisco.
author: Xin G.

description: Not the best sushi for the wait there was. Maybe check another place out first. The servers was ok but too fast for a sushi place. Slow down and enjoy. Kinda feels like a turn and burn place.
author: Robert S.

description: Absolutely delicious. The fish was fresh and the service was good. The chips and dip was fantastic. And the flaming Seabass was excellent.
author: Mike J.

description:
Mouthwatering nigiri and sashimi. We went there as a party of 3 without reservations on a Tuesday night at ~7pm, and waited a full 40 minutes before being seated. When we were heading towards the table, we heard the hostess tell a group of 3 that it'd be a 1.5 hour wait. So yes, get there early!! 

As for the food, we got 2 omakase sashimi. Delicious. The salmon especially was absolutely mouthwatering. The chefs were generous with their cuts, even with the o-toro nigiri! 

All is all, with beers and tea, the bill came out to be ~$150 with tip for a party of 3. 

Service was hectic, but expected when there's that many people in such a small space. The only thing that brought this down to 4 stars is that the other fusion foods were not done as well. We had the blue fin tuna bites, which were bland and smothered in olive oil -- a shame considering how fresh the fish was.
author: Christine H.

description:
We were a party of 4 (apparently thats quite large for this type of establishment). As I was in the midst of putting in the seabass roll in my mouth, the waitress came to kick us out. She said to us "your 1 hour and 30  mins are up, I need you guys to settle the bill". WTF?!?!? This is the most ridiculous thing i've ever heard. I was still eating and my group was still ordering drinks. Our bill was practically $200 so it wasn't like we were bums just loitering around to waste time. They should've told us the restaurant rule prior to us sitting down. 

The group of 5 that we were sharing tables with, also got kicked out as they were drinking their beers. They came in 30 mins after us. SO I am not sure how they are keeping tabs. We were all so fed up that we walked out with the beers in our hands. 

If you are going to run an establishment, make sure you work on providing good customer service.
author: Ying L.

description: Called and made a reservation after seeing a massive line the other night. My boyfriend and I love sushi and have been to multiple places around SF and the peninsula. We saw how great the ratings were and said we have to give it a try. However, it was kind of a let down. The rolls were great, but nothing special about them. I definitely think it's all hype.
author: Nickie F.

description:
Easily the best sushi spot in the city. Not as authentic as some spots, but you get the absolute best bang for your buck here. 

Highlights:
Yah man 
Basil salmon
White out
Himalayan trout 
Everything 

I come here at least two times per month and have never been disappointed. Plan to wait about an hour on a weekend, but luckily there's an adorable little wine bar just two doors down! Worth the wait, every time.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Me, "Hi, how busy are you tonight?" 
Hostess,  "Very busy"
Silent pause. 
Me, "Should I come by and wait then?"
Hostess, "No."
Silent pause. 
Me, "OK"
Hostess, hung up. Zero response.  
Me,  went to Sushi Rapture.
author: Harland K.

description: One of my favorite sushi places in SF. Try the flaming sea bass while you're there, they light it on fire to cook it at your table and it's amazing! I'd recommend going on a weekday as the weekends is very crowded (as the restaurant itself is not very large). If you go on the weekend, plan to get there 15 minutes before it opens to not have to wait.
author: Cameron R.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi spots in the city. Fresh fish, good service, cute interior, amazing (and unique) menu selections.
author: Thalia H.

description:
I have watched elephant sushi get more and more popular over the past year, so I finally decided to see what all the fuss was about and took my friend from out of town on Saturday night. I made reservations a few days ahead and we 100% needed them, even for 2. This is a tiny restaurant with maybe 10 tables and it is always filled.

They obviously heard what I said about portion sizes (I'm gonna go ahead and give myself credit for this, thanks) because this time we ended up paying less and had way too much food.

We ordered the ya man roll which I was skeptical because pesto and sushi? But it was super amazing! We also had the double hamachi, red and yellow, and the white-out roll.  Everything was delicious, creative, and very fresh. 

The hostess here is super friendly. We were seated by the door and watched as people without reservations came in. She was totally on it, finding tables where she could and graciously turning people away when she couldn't. Seriously, other restaurants take note!

I'll chalk up my previous experience to them being new and would definitely recommend elephant sushi! I'm 110% certain I'll be back.
author: Rachel E.

description: Flaming sea bass roll, Giants roll, Red & Yellow roll, Spicy Hamachi. House made pickled ginger. If there is a wait, grab a glass of wine or beer at Union Larder across the street first. Someday I'll learn how to use chop sticks!
author: Andrew K.

description: Great rolls but apparently they're too good to serve edamame. My favorite rolls was the white dragon.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Easily one of the best, if not the best, sushi spots I have ever been too!! I was visiting San Francisco and was in the mood for sushi and saw the great reviews so me and my husband thought we'd give it a shot. At first we were so hungry and didn't feel like waiting but it was a short wait 20-30 minutes and I am so glad we did! It's a tiny place but everything is soooo good! We had sake bombs (only $2) and I had 2 hello kitty martinis ($5!!) which were on the happy hour special. We ate the Himalayan salt salmon which was hands down the best salmon we've ever eaten. So fresh and it was like butter! We also are Godzilla and a few other rolls which were also delicious. We of course had to try the flaming sea bass which was probably our least favorite but still very good. We did it for the experience. 

HIGHLY RECOMMEND !!!! it was tough to find parking but well worth the hassle. Trust me!
author: Leslie S.

description:
Here what sucks - Parking. Calling the server more than three times for a refill (bf's tea). Noise.

Here's what's great.  Fish (tender, well selected) .  Maki (more avocado than rice). Price (worth every penny).  The Seabass presentation is cool (Foiled fish flambé) - $16 ... the Rainbow roll ($14), the Poke was really good ($12) - all prices in memory, I didn't pay (hah!) Oh, $15 corkage.  6 seats at the sushi bar and restroom was noisy.

So, take public transportation, drink sake bombs ($2 all day), and "sign" and it will be 5 stars.

Hint: they offer Swensen's ice cream for dessert - go up the block and save $3 and it's not noisy.
author: Andrea K.

description: Love this place. It gets packed right after they open. And it is worth it:)
author: Midori I.

description:
Sushi = super fresh and creative 
Service = friendly and knowledgable
Vibe = energetic and low key
5 stars all around!
author: Michelle B.

description: This is my favorite sushi place EVER!!!!!!!!!  I'm a major foodie and really hard to please.  Absolutely blown away by this gem!!!!! :-D Great lil date spot too!  Get there early, put your name on the list, and grab a drink next door while you wait for Elephant to call your cell when your table is ready.  I never understood what people meant when they described raw fish being so fresh that it "melted" in their mouths - until I came here.  Totally get it now!!!! LOVVVVVVE this spot :)))))
author: Deanna T.

description:
Best sushi restaurant I've ever been to. If you like sushi you must try this place out. 

We started off with a couple of Hello Kitty martinis, which were very reasonably process due to Happy Hour (all night) and the Hawaiian Poki salad. Poki was ahi tuna and wonderful. It's more of a salad so the tuna is mixed with seaweed. Mayonnaise dressing was good.

The sushi was the best past. We ordered the Flaming Sea Bass, Whiteout, and Boom Box. Very, very distinct flavors between the three. Whiteout has a very citrusy, like flavor, which you usually don't get with sushi. The Boom Box had toasted bananas on the top. Very sweet and probably wouldn't opt for that next time (tasted like dessert). Flaming Sea Bass is very unique and absolutely mouthwatering. It's cooked right in front of you on gasoline for 8 minutes. So it's hot sushi, which I've never had before. Definitely getting that the next time I go. 

Service was five out of five. The waitress even charged my iPhone for me while I was eating. We were seated ten minutes after putting our name down on a Saturday night. 

Will definitely be revisiting!
author: Viroopa V.

description:
Usually I don't go to places that specializes rolls as they usually have poor quality fishes and lose the authenticity. However, their fishes were quite good. Sashimi and nigiri sushi were very nice too. I like how they have some fishes that are not common in other sushi places such as sea bass and ocean trout. I would love to come back again.

Couple things I didn't like about this place:

The wait was too long. It was freezing cold outside. With a baby in my arm and stood for an hour, we were getting impatient. It'd be nice if they can have a better waiting system. Maybe text you when table is ready?

We were not full and would like to order more. We call the waiter over, but he actually brought us our check. We know the place is very small and packed, but we felt like we were getting kicked out without having enough.

Flaming Seabass was tasty, but it would fall apart when pick up by chopsticks. We asked the waiter for spoons, and it took a while since all their spoons were in the washer at the time...
author: Karen N.

description: It's a very very tiny restaurant so finding a place to sit can be tough. The line usually starts about 15 minutes before the restaurant opens, and your entire party has to be with you at that time, no saving tables. But once you get a spot, you'll be very satisfied with their sushi options. Everything melts in your mouth and you want to just keep eating as much as you can! One of my top 5 sushi places in San Francisco.
author: Samara C.

description:
Such fresh & inventive sushi! 

Came with a girlfriend at 8 PM on a Thursday night and had to wait ~3 minutes before a table opened up at the sushi bar.  The chef gave us two pieces of their butterfish (walu) sashimi on the house, which was FANTASTIC and melted in your mouth.  My friend had never had butterfish before and definitely got a great first impression. 

We ordered drinks (dry sake which came out in a cute martini glass) and the sashimi combo (very generous portions and great cuts of fish.  The salmon was some of the best that I've had in the city so far).   We also ordered the White Out roll after seeing it all over yelp and it is goooooooooooooooood.  I would come back just to eat that roll over and over again.  The housemade ginger was also delicious (I ate an embarrassingly large amount of it). 

I am already planning when I can come back and try some of the other rolls.  I would probably only come here with a party of 2 unless you have reservations though since it is a tiny place but worth it!
author: Raina D.

description: No American express, no more 2 credit cards, no edadme, no eel, Why do I keep coming back here? Otherwise the salmon is pretty good.
author: Todd E.

description:
Everything here is mind-blowingly delicious (especially the albacore tataki and white out roll), and arriving before they open/calling ahead can seriously cut your wait time down. They even take your phone number down, so you can wander over to Polk for drinks/Loving Cup while waiting.

The waitress said I reminded her of someone she knows, and while being indirectly told you have a generic looking face may have bothered some, I just enjoyed the good food and the extra friendly service.

Besides the seating being pretty cramped and the decision to eat here having to be extremely premeditated (or long wait for some), it's a great place for sushi and quite possibly a fantastic location to wow a date.
author: Nick W.

description: I love the food here, and I wish I could write a better review, but the quality of their food does not make up for their lack of service. They claim to not take reservations, but somehow every time I've ever gone and waited in line for 1+ hour, there has always been someone who has walked up, mentioned a reservation, and been seated right away. After a few times of this happening, I finally asked the host how we could obtain reservations in the future, and they pretended like they had no idea what I was talking about. Seriously? I was just right in front of you when someone walked up and said they had a reservation? If you have 1-2+ hours to wait in line on the street to get seated - do it, but I'm not so sure it's worth the wait and don't understand why they won't just open up some reservation tables. After eating here more than 10+ times, I decided to try Okoze around the corner. Just as good of quality, 1/4 the length of wait time, and they DO accept reservations :)
author: Laura T.

description: It's like a little tiny hidden pearl in the middle of a busy street. Make sure you make reservations a day in advance and leave early, because traffic+trying to find parking=1hr&15 min especially coming from Daly City. Service : 4Stars. Food quality: 5Stars. I liked: Flaming sea bass, Blue find tuna w/shaved truffles & beastie boys "I think"! Definitely not good for groups. There's only 1 table for 4, 1 table for 6 I think and the rest is for couples.
author: Sal T.

description: The food was alright. Just some gimmick food. Be careful though, they will change your total amount  after you leave! Watch for your credit card bill
author: Cass Z.

description:
We came here for the soft launch opening so the menu was limited but we went to town!  And everything was amazing!  High quality fish and impressive menu.

My faves: 
- Torched Mackerel Tataki
- White Out Hamachi Roll
- 4 piece Nigiri Tasting
- Flaming Seabass House Special Roll - it comes out on fire and isn't just a gimmick, actually delicious! 

Ambiance is great and the hostess and waiters were super friendly.  Be back soon...

*****
Went back on 9/7 and it was EVEN MORE AMAZING!  The menu is growing so we tried 1 of everything!!  Not a single item disappointed.  My fave: trout on Himalayan salt plank.

Make sure to ask about off-menu items ;)

*****
Okay, I may need to cut myself off but we went again on 9/13.  Two people split 4 rolls and we were both STUFFED!  We got the special rolls, including Double Albacore and Phat Roll which were fantastic.
author: Anh D.

description:
Wow. This place is great. The beastie boys and sea bass were unique and delicious. I would go back here just for that.

Luckily we arrived early and were able to sit right away, this place filled up quickly. Can't wait to come back here the next time I'm in SF.
author: Fred P.

description:
Great sushi, very fresh fish and a good selection of rolls and sashimi. 

The dining area is very small and you almost certainly need a reservation to eat here. The staff is very friendly and they kept refilling our water regularly, which is something that I definitely appreciate. 

There isn't much parking around this area of Russian Hill, but it is on a cute little part of Hyde. 

I would definitely come back here.
author: Cara C.

description:
Took my family here last year (4 little kids who destroy sushi like tornadoes in trailer parks).
